2778 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = None,
2779 value_labels: dict[Hashable, dict[float, str]] | None = None,
2780 ) -> None:
2781 """
2782 Export DataFrame object to Stata dta format.
2783
2784 Writes the DataFrame to a Stata dataset file.
2785 "dta" files contain a Stata dataset.
2786
2787 Parameters
2788 ----------
2789 path : str, path object, or buffer
2790 String, path object (implementing ``os.PathLike[str]``), or file-like
2791 object implementing a binary ``write()`` function.
2792
2793 convert_dates : dict
2794 Dictionary mapping columns containing datetime types to stata
2795 internal format to use when writing the dates. Options are 'tc',
2796 'td', 'tm', 'tw', 'th', 'tq', 'ty'. Column can be either an integer
2797 or a name. Datetime columns that do not have a conversion type
2798 specified will be converted to 'tc'. Raises NotImplementedError if
2799 a datetime column has timezone information.
2800 write_index : bool
2801 Write the index to Stata dataset.
2802 byteorder : str
2803 Can be ">", "<", "little", or "big". default is `sys.byteorder`.
2804 time_stamp : datetime
2805 A datetime to use as file creation date. Default is the current
2806 time.
2807 data_label : str, optional
2808 A label for the data set. Must be 80 characters or smaller.
2809 variable_labels : dict
2810 Dictionary containing columns as keys and variable labels as
2811 values. Each label must be 80 characters or smaller.
2812 version : {{114, 117, 118, 119, None}}, default 114
2813 Version to use in the output dta file. Set to None to let pandas
2814 decide between 118 or 119 formats depending on the number of
2815 columns in the frame. Version 114 can be read by Stata 10 and
2816 later. Version 117 can be read by Stata 13 or later. Version 118
2817 is supported in Stata 14 and later. Version 119 is supported in
2818 Stata 15 and later. Version 114 limits string variables to 244
2819 characters or fewer while versions 117 and later allow strings
2820 with lengths up to 2,000,000 characters. Versions 118 and 119
2821 support Unicode characters, and version 119 supports more than
2822 32,767 variables.
2823
2824 Version 119 should usually only be used when the number of
2825 variables exceeds the capacity of dta format 118. Exporting
2826 smaller datasets in format 119 may have unintended consequences,
2827 and, as of November 2020, Stata SE cannot read version 119 files.
2828
2829 convert_strl : list, optional
2830 List of column names to convert to string columns to Stata StrL
2831 format. Only available if version is 117. Storing strings in the
2832 StrL format can produce smaller dta files if strings have more than
2833 8 characters and values are repeated.
2834 {compression_options}
2835
2836 .. versionchanged:: 1.4.0 Zstandard support.
2837
2838 {storage_options}
2839
2840 value_labels : dict of dicts
2841 Dictionary containing columns as keys and dictionaries of column value
2842 to labels as values. Labels for a single variable must be 32,000
2843 characters or smaller.
2844
2845 .. versionadded:: 1.4.0
2846
2847 Raises
2848 ------
2849 NotImplementedError
2850 * If datetimes contain timezone information
2851 * Column dtype is not representable in Stata
2852 ValueError
2853 * Columns listed in convert_dates are neither datetime64[ns]
2854 or datetime.datetime
2855 * Column listed in convert_dates is not in DataFrame
2856 * Categorical label contains more than 32,000 characters
2857
2858 See Also
2859 --------
2860 read_stata : Import Stata data files.
2861 io.stata.StataWriter : Low-level writer for Stata data files.
2862 io.stata.StataWriter117 : Low-level writer for version 117 files.
2863
2864 Examples
2865 --------
2866 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({{'animal': ['falcon', 'parrot', 'falcon',
2867 ... 'parrot'],
2868 ... 'speed': [350, 18, 361, 15]}})
2869 >>> df.to_stata('animals.dta') # doctest: +SKIP
2870 """
2871 if version not in (114, 117, 118, 119, None):
2872 raise ValueError("Only formats 114, 117, 118 and 119 are supported.")
2873 if version == 114:
2874 if convert_strl is not None:
2875 raise ValueError("strl is not supported in format 114")
2876 from pandas.io.stata import StataWriter as statawriter
2877 elif version == 117:
2878 # Incompatible import of "statawriter" (imported name has type
2879 # "Type[StataWriter117]", local name has type "Type[StataWriter]")
2880 from pandas.io.stata import ( # type: ignore[assignment]
2881 StataWriter117 as statawriter,
2882 )
2883 else: # versions 118 and 119
2884 # Incompatible import of "statawriter" (imported name has type
2885 # "Type[StataWriter117]", local name has type "Type[StataWriter]")
2886 from pandas.io.stata import ( # type: ignore[assignment]
2887 StataWriterUTF8 as statawriter,
2888 )
2889
2890 kwargs: dict[str, Any] = {}
2891 if version is None or version >= 117:
2892 # strl conversion is only supported >= 117
2893 kwargs["convert_strl"] = convert_strl
2894 if version is None or version >= 118:
2895 # Specifying the version is only supported for UTF8 (118 or 119)
2896 kwargs["version"] = version
2897
2898 writer = statawriter(
2899 path,
2900 self,
2901 convert_dates=convert_dates,
2902 byteorder=byteorder,
2903 time_stamp=time_stamp,
2904 data_label=data_label,
2905 write_index=write_index,
2906 variable_labels=variable_labels,
2907 compression=compression,
2908 storage_options=storage_options,
2909 value_labels=value_labels,
2910 **kwargs,
2911 )
2912 writer.write_file()
2913
2914 def to_feather(self, path: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes], **kwargs) -> None:
2915 """
2916 Write a DataFrame to the binary Feather format.
2917
2918 Parameters
2919 ----------
2920 path : str, path object, file-like object
2921 String, path object (implementing ``os.PathLike[str]``), or file-like
2922 object implementing a binary ``write()`` function. If a string or a path,
2923 it will be used as Root Directory path when writing a partitioned dataset.
2924 **kwargs :
2925 Additional keywords passed to :func:`pyarrow.feather.write_feather`.
2926 This includes the `compression`, `compression_level`, `chunksize`
2927 and `version` keywords.
2928
2929 Notes
2930 -----
2931 This function writes the dataframe as a `feather file
2932 <https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/feather.html>`_. Requires a default
2933 index. For saving the DataFrame with your custom index use a method that
2934 supports custom indices e.g. `to_parquet`.
2935
2936 Examples
2937 --------
2938 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]])
2939 >>> df.to_feather("file.feather") # doctest: +SKIP
2940 """
2941 from pandas.io.feather_format import to_feather
2942
2943 to_feather(self, path, **kwargs)
2944
2945 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(
2946 version="3.0", allowed_args=["self", "buf"], name="to_markdown"
2947 )
2948 @doc(
2949 Series.to_markdown,
2950 klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"],
2951 storage_options=_shared_docs["storage_options"],
2952 examples="""Examples
2953 --------
2954 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(
2955 ... data={"animal_1": ["elk", "pig"], "animal_2": ["dog", "quetzal"]}
2956 ... )
2957 >>> print(df.to_markdown())
2958 | | animal_1 | animal_2 |
2959 |---:|:-----------|:-----------|
2960 | 0 | elk | dog |
2961 | 1 | pig | quetzal |
2962
2963 Output markdown with a tabulate option.
2964
2965 >>> print(df.to_markdown(tablefmt="grid"))
2966 +----+------------+------------+
2967 | | animal_1 | animal_2 |
2968 +====+============+============+
2969 | 0 | elk | dog |
2970 +----+------------+------------+
2971 | 1 | pig | quetzal |
2972 +----+------------+------------+""",
2973 )
2974 def to_markdown(
2975 self,
2976 buf: FilePath | WriteBuffer[str] | None = None,
2977 mode: str = "wt",
2978 index: bool = True,
2979 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = None,
2980 **kwargs,
2981 ) -> str | None:
2982 if "showindex" in kwargs:
2983 raise ValueError("Pass 'index' instead of 'showindex")
2984
2985 kwargs.setdefault("headers", "keys")
2986 kwargs.setdefault("tablefmt", "pipe")
2987 kwargs.setdefault("showindex", index)
2988 tabulate = import_optional_dependency("tabulate")
2989 result = tabulate.tabulate(self, **kwargs)
2990 if buf is None:
2991 return result
2992
2993 with get_handle(buf, mode, storage_options=storage_options) as handles:
2994 handles.handle.write(result)
2995 return None
2996
2997 @overload
2998 def to_parquet(
2999 self,
3000 path: None = ...,
3001 engine: Literal["auto", "pyarrow", "fastparquet"] = ...,
3002 compression: str | None = ...,
3003 index: bool | None = ...,
3004 partition_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3005 storage_options: StorageOptions = ...,
3006 **kwargs,
3007 ) -> bytes:
3008 ...
3009
3010 @overload
3011 def to_parquet(
3012 self,
3013 path: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes],
3014 engine: Literal["auto", "pyarrow", "fastparquet"] = ...,
3015 compression: str | None = ...,
3016 index: bool | None = ...,
3017 partition_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3018 storage_options: StorageOptions = ...,
3019 **kwargs,
3020 ) -> None:
3021 ...
3022
3023 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(
3024 version="3.0", allowed_args=["self", "path"], name="to_parquet"
3025 )
3026 @doc(storage_options=_shared_docs["storage_options"])
3027 def to_parquet(
3028 self,
3029 path: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes] | None = None,
3030 engine: Literal["auto", "pyarrow", "fastparquet"] = "auto",
3031 compression: str | None = "snappy",
3032 index: bool | None = None,
3033 partition_cols: list[str] | None = None,
3034 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = None,
3035 **kwargs,
3036 ) -> bytes | None:
3037 """
3038 Write a DataFrame to the binary parquet format.
3039
3040 This function writes the dataframe as a `parquet file
3041 <https://parquet.apache.org/>`_. You can choose different parquet
3042 backends, and have the option of compression. See
3043 :ref:`the user guide <io.parquet>` for more details.
3044
3045 Parameters
3046 ----------
3047 path : str, path object, file-like object, or None, default None
3048 String, path object (implementing ``os.PathLike[str]``), or file-like
3049 object implementing a binary ``write()`` function. If None, the result is
3050 returned as bytes. If a string or path, it will be used as Root Directory
3051 path when writing a partitioned dataset.
3052 engine : {{'auto', 'pyarrow', 'fastparquet'}}, default 'auto'
3053 Parquet library to use. If 'auto', then the option
3054 ``io.parquet.engine`` is used. The default ``io.parquet.engine``
3055 behavior is to try 'pyarrow', falling back to 'fastparquet' if
3056 'pyarrow' is unavailable.
3057 compression : str or None, default 'snappy'
3058 Name of the compression to use. Use ``None`` for no compression.
3059 Supported options: 'snappy', 'gzip', 'brotli', 'lz4', 'zstd'.
3060 index : bool, default None
3061 If ``True``, include the dataframe's index(es) in the file output.
3062 If ``False``, they will not be written to the file.
3063 If ``None``, similar to ``True`` the dataframe's index(es)
3064 will be saved. However, instead of being saved as values,
3065 the RangeIndex will be stored as a range in the metadata so it
3066 doesn't require much space and is faster. Other indexes will
3067 be included as columns in the file output.
3068 partition_cols : list, optional, default None
3069 Column names by which to partition the dataset.
3070 Columns are partitioned in the order they are given.
3071 Must be None if path is not a string.
3072 {storage_options}
3073
3074 **kwargs
3075 Additional arguments passed to the parquet library. See
3076 :ref:`pandas io <io.parquet>` for more details.
3077
3078 Returns
3079 -------
3080 bytes if no path argument is provided else None
3081
3082 See Also
3083 --------
3084 read_parquet : Read a parquet file.
3085 DataFrame.to_orc : Write an orc file.
3086 DataFrame.to_csv : Write a csv file.
3087 DataFrame.to_sql : Write to a sql table.
3088 DataFrame.to_hdf : Write to hdf.
3089
3090 Notes
3091 -----
3092 This function requires either the `fastparquet
3093 <https://pypi.org/project/fastparquet>`_ or `pyarrow
3094 <https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/>`_ library.
3095
3096 Examples
3097 --------
3098 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data={{'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]}})
3099 >>> df.to_parquet('df.parquet.gzip',
3100 ... compression='gzip') # doctest: +SKIP
3101 >>> pd.read_parquet('df.parquet.gzip') # doctest: +SKIP
3102 col1 col2
3103 0 1 3
3104 1 2 4
3105
3106 If you want to get a buffer to the parquet content you can use a io.BytesIO
3107 object, as long as you don't use partition_cols, which creates multiple files.
3108
3109 >>> import io
3110 >>> f = io.BytesIO()
3111 >>> df.to_parquet(f)
3112 >>> f.seek(0)
3113 0
3114 >>> content = f.read()
3115 """
3116 from pandas.io.parquet import to_parquet
3117
3118 return to_parquet(
3119 self,
3120 path,
3121 engine,
3122 compression=compression,
3123 index=index,
3124 partition_cols=partition_cols,
3125 storage_options=storage_options,
3126 **kwargs,
3127 )
3128
3129 def to_orc(
3130 self,
3131 path: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes] | None = None,
3132 *,
3133 engine: Literal["pyarrow"] = "pyarrow",
3134 index: bool | None = None,
3135 engine_kwargs: dict[str, Any] | None = None,
3136 ) -> bytes | None:
3137 """
3138 Write a DataFrame to the ORC format.
3139
3140 .. versionadded:: 1.5.0
3141
3142 Parameters
3143 ----------
3144 path : str, file-like object or None, default None
3145 If a string, it will be used as Root Directory path
3146 when writing a partitioned dataset. By file-like object,
3147 we refer to objects with a write() method, such as a file handle
3148 (e.g. via builtin open function). If path is None,
3149 a bytes object is returned.
3150 engine : {'pyarrow'}, default 'pyarrow'
3151 ORC library to use.
3152 index : bool, optional
3153 If ``True``, include the dataframe's index(es) in the file output.
3154 If ``False``, they will not be written to the file.
3155 If ``None``, similar to ``infer`` the dataframe's index(es)
3156 will be saved. However, instead of being saved as values,
3157 the RangeIndex will be stored as a range in the metadata so it
3158 doesn't require much space and is faster. Other indexes will
3159 be included as columns in the file output.
3160 engine_kwargs : dict[str, Any] or None, default None
3161 Additional keyword arguments passed to :func:`pyarrow.orc.write_table`.
3162
3163 Returns
3164 -------
3165 bytes if no path argument is provided else None
3166
3167 Raises
3168 ------
3169 NotImplementedError
3170 Dtype of one or more columns is category, unsigned integers, interval,
3171 period or sparse.
3172 ValueError
3173 engine is not pyarrow.
3174
3175 See Also
3176 --------
3177 read_orc : Read a ORC file.
3178 DataFrame.to_parquet : Write a parquet file.
3179 DataFrame.to_csv : Write a csv file.
3180 DataFrame.to_sql : Write to a sql table.
3181 DataFrame.to_hdf : Write to hdf.
3182
3183 Notes
3184 -----
3185 * Before using this function you should read the :ref:`user guide about
3186 ORC <io.orc>` and :ref:`install optional dependencies <install.warn_orc>`.
3187 * This function requires `pyarrow <https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/>`_
3188 library.
3189 * For supported dtypes please refer to `supported ORC features in Arrow
3190 <https://arrow.apache.org/docs/cpp/orc.html#data-types>`__.
3191 * Currently timezones in datetime columns are not preserved when a
3192 dataframe is converted into ORC files.
3193
3194 Examples
3195 --------
3196 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data={'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [4, 3]})
3197 >>> df.to_orc('df.orc') # doctest: +SKIP
3198 >>> pd.read_orc('df.orc') # doctest: +SKIP
3199 col1 col2
3200 0 1 4
3201 1 2 3
3202
3203 If you want to get a buffer to the orc content you can write it to io.BytesIO
3204
3205 >>> import io
3206 >>> b = io.BytesIO(df.to_orc()) # doctest: +SKIP
3207 >>> b.seek(0) # doctest: +SKIP
3208 0
3209 >>> content = b.read() # doctest: +SKIP
3210 """
3211 from pandas.io.orc import to_orc
3212
3213 return to_orc(
3214 self, path, engine=engine, index=index, engine_kwargs=engine_kwargs
3215 )
3216
3217 @overload
3218 def to_html(
3219 self,
3220 buf: FilePath | WriteBuffer[str],
3221 columns: Axes | None = ...,
3222 col_space: ColspaceArgType | None = ...,
3223 header: bool = ...,
3224 index: bool = ...,
3225 na_rep: str = ...,
3226 formatters: FormattersType | None = ...,
3227 float_format: FloatFormatType | None = ...,
3228 sparsify: bool | None = ...,
3229 index_names: bool = ...,
3230 justify: str | None = ...,
3231 max_rows: int | None = ...,
3232 max_cols: int | None = ...,
3233 show_dimensions: bool | str = ...,
3234 decimal: str = ...,
3235 bold_rows: bool = ...,
3236 classes: str | list | tuple | None = ...,
3237 escape: bool = ...,
3238 notebook: bool = ...,
3239 border: int | bool | None = ...,
3240 table_id: str | None = ...,
3241 render_links: bool = ...,
3242 encoding: str | None = ...,
3243 ) -> None:
3244 ...
3245
3246 @overload
3247 def to_html(
3248 self,
3249 buf: None = ...,
3250 columns: Axes | None = ...,
3251 col_space: ColspaceArgType | None = ...,
3252 header: bool = ...,
3253 index: bool = ...,
3254 na_rep: str = ...,
3255 formatters: FormattersType | None = ...,
3256 float_format: FloatFormatType | None = ...,
3257 sparsify: bool | None = ...,
3258 index_names: bool = ...,
3259 justify: str | None = ...,
3260 max_rows: int | None = ...,
3261 max_cols: int | None = ...,
3262 show_dimensions: bool | str = ...,
3263 decimal: str = ...,
3264 bold_rows: bool = ...,
3265 classes: str | list | tuple | None = ...,
3266 escape: bool = ...,
3267 notebook: bool = ...,
3268 border: int | bool | None = ...,
3269 table_id: str | None = ...,
3270 render_links: bool = ...,
3271 encoding: str | None = ...,
3272 ) -> str:
3273 ...
3274
3275 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(
3276 version="3.0", allowed_args=["self", "buf"], name="to_html"
3277 )
3278 @Substitution(
3279 header_type="bool",
3280 header="Whether to print column labels, default True",
3281 col_space_type="str or int, list or dict of int or str",
3282 col_space="The minimum width of each column in CSS length "
3283 "units. An int is assumed to be px units.",
3284 )
3285 @Substitution(shared_params=fmt.common_docstring, returns=fmt.return_docstring)
3286 def to_html(
3287 self,
3288 buf: FilePath | WriteBuffer[str] | None = None,
3289 columns: Axes | None = None,
3290 col_space: ColspaceArgType | None = None,
3291 header: bool = True,
3292 index: bool = True,
3293 na_rep: str = "NaN",
3294 formatters: FormattersType | None = None,
3295 float_format: FloatFormatType | None = None,
3296 sparsify: bool | None = None,
3297 index_names: bool = True,
3298 justify: str | None = None,
3299 max_rows: int | None = None,
3300 max_cols: int | None = None,
3301 show_dimensions: bool | str = False,
3302 decimal: str = ".",
3303 bold_rows: bool = True,
3304 classes: str | list | tuple | None = None,
3305 escape: bool = True,
3306 notebook: bool = False,
3307 border: int | bool | None = None,
3308 table_id: str | None = None,
3309 render_links: bool = False,
3310 encoding: str | None = None,
3311 ) -> str | None:
3312 """
3313 Render a DataFrame as an HTML table.
3314 %(shared_params)s
3315 bold_rows : bool, default True
3316 Make the row labels bold in the output.
3317 classes : str or list or tuple, default None
3318 CSS class(es) to apply to the resulting html table.
3319 escape : bool, default True
3320 Convert the characters <, >, and & to HTML-safe sequences.
3321 notebook : {True, False}, default False
3322 Whether the generated HTML is for IPython Notebook.
3323 border : int
3324 A ``border=border`` attribute is included in the opening
3325 `<table>` tag. Default ``pd.options.display.html.border``.
3326 table_id : str, optional
3327 A css id is included in the opening `<table>` tag if specified.
3328 render_links : bool, default False
3329 Convert URLs to HTML links.
3330 encoding : str, default "utf-8"
3331 Set character encoding.
3332 %(returns)s
3333 See Also
3334 --------
3335 to_string : Convert DataFrame to a string.
3336
3337 Examples
3338 --------
3339 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data={'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [4, 3]})
3340 >>> html_string = '''<table border="1" class="dataframe">
3341 ... <thead>
3342 ... <tr style="text-align: right;">
3343 ... <th></th>
3344 ... <th>col1</th>
3345 ... <th>col2</th>
3346 ... </tr>
3347 ... </thead>
3348 ... <tbody>
3349 ... <tr>
3350 ... <th>0</th>
3351 ... <td>1</td>
3352 ... <td>4</td>
3353 ... </tr>
3354 ... <tr>
3355 ... <th>1</th>
3356 ... <td>2</td>
3357 ... <td>3</td>
3358 ... </tr>
3359 ... </tbody>
3360 ... </table>'''
3361 >>> assert html_string == df.to_html()
3362 """
3363 if justify is not None and justify not in fmt.VALID_JUSTIFY_PARAMETERS:
3364 raise ValueError("Invalid value for justify parameter")
3365
3366 formatter = fmt.DataFrameFormatter(
3367 self,
3368 columns=columns,
3369 col_space=col_space,
3370 na_rep=na_rep,
3371 header=header,
3372 index=index,
3373 formatters=formatters,
3374 float_format=float_format,
3375 bold_rows=bold_rows,
3376 sparsify=sparsify,
3377 justify=justify,
3378 index_names=index_names,
3379 escape=escape,
3380 decimal=decimal,
3381 max_rows=max_rows,
3382 max_cols=max_cols,
3383 show_dimensions=show_dimensions,
3384 )
3385 # TODO: a generic formatter wld b in DataFrameFormatter
3386 return fmt.DataFrameRenderer(formatter).to_html(
3387 buf=buf,
3388 classes=classes,
3389 notebook=notebook,
3390 border=border,
3391 encoding=encoding,
3392 table_id=table_id,
3393 render_links=render_links,
3394 )
3395
3396 @overload
3397 def to_xml(
3398 self,
3399 path_or_buffer: None = ...,
3400 *,
3401 index: bool = ...,
3402 root_name: str | None = ...,
3403 row_name: str | None = ...,
3404 na_rep: str | None = ...,
3405 attr_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3406 elem_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3407 namespaces: dict[str | None, str] | None = ...,
3408 prefix: str | None = ...,
3409 encoding: str = ...,
3410 xml_declaration: bool | None = ...,
3411 pretty_print: bool | None = ...,
3412 parser: XMLParsers | None = ...,
3413 stylesheet: FilePath | ReadBuffer[str] | ReadBuffer[bytes] | None = ...,
3414 compression: CompressionOptions = ...,
3415 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = ...,
3416 ) -> str:
3417 ...
3418
3419 @overload
3420 def to_xml(
3421 self,
3422 path_or_buffer: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes] | WriteBuffer[str],
3423 *,
3424 index: bool = ...,
3425 root_name: str | None = ...,
3426 row_name: str | None = ...,
3427 na_rep: str | None = ...,
3428 attr_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3429 elem_cols: list[str] | None = ...,
3430 namespaces: dict[str | None, str] | None = ...,
3431 prefix: str | None = ...,
3432 encoding: str = ...,
3433 xml_declaration: bool | None = ...,
3434 pretty_print: bool | None = ...,
3435 parser: XMLParsers | None = ...,
3436 stylesheet: FilePath | ReadBuffer[str] | ReadBuffer[bytes] | None = ...,
3437 compression: CompressionOptions = ...,
3438 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = ...,
3439 ) -> None:
3440 ...
3441
3442 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(
3443 version="3.0", allowed_args=["self", "path_or_buffer"], name="to_xml"
3444 )
3445 @doc(
3446 storage_options=_shared_docs["storage_options"],
3447 compression_options=_shared_docs["compression_options"] % "path_or_buffer",
3448 )
3449 def to_xml(
3450 self,
3451 path_or_buffer: FilePath | WriteBuffer[bytes] | WriteBuffer[str] | None = None,
3452 index: bool = True,
3453 root_name: str | None = "data",
3454 row_name: str | None = "row",
3455 na_rep: str | None = None,
3456 attr_cols: list[str] | None = None,
3457 elem_cols: list[str] | None = None,
3458 namespaces: dict[str | None, str] | None = None,
3459 prefix: str | None = None,
3460 encoding: str = "utf-8",
3461 xml_declaration: bool | None = True,
3462 pretty_print: bool | None = True,
3463 parser: XMLParsers | None = "lxml",
3464 stylesheet: FilePath | ReadBuffer[str] | ReadBuffer[bytes] | None = None,
3465 compression: CompressionOptions = "infer",
3466 storage_options: StorageOptions | None = None,
3467 ) -> str | None:
3468 """
3469 Render a DataFrame to an XML document.
3470
3471 .. versionadded:: 1.3.0
3472
3473 Parameters
3474 ----------
3475 path_or_buffer : str, path object, file-like object, or None, default None
3476 String, path object (implementing ``os.PathLike[str]``), or file-like
3477 object implementing a ``write()`` function. If None, the result is returned
3478 as a string.
3479 index : bool, default True
3480 Whether to include index in XML document.
3481 root_name : str, default 'data'
3482 The name of root element in XML document.
3483 row_name : str, default 'row'
3484 The name of row element in XML document.
3485 na_rep : str, optional
3486 Missing data representation.
3487 attr_cols : list-like, optional
3488 List of columns to write as attributes in row element.
3489 Hierarchical columns will be flattened with underscore
3490 delimiting the different levels.
3491 elem_cols : list-like, optional
3492 List of columns to write as children in row element. By default,
3493 all columns output as children of row element. Hierarchical
3494 columns will be flattened with underscore delimiting the
3495 different levels.
3496 namespaces : dict, optional
3497 All namespaces to be defined in root element. Keys of dict
3498 should be prefix names and values of dict corresponding URIs.
3499 Default namespaces should be given empty string key. For
3500 example, ::
3501
3502 namespaces = {{"": "https://example.com"}}
3503
3504 prefix : str, optional
3505 Namespace prefix to be used for every element and/or attribute
3506 in document. This should be one of the keys in ``namespaces``
3507 dict.
3508 encoding : str, default 'utf-8'
3509 Encoding of the resulting document.
3510 xml_declaration : bool, default True
3511 Whether to include the XML declaration at start of document.
3512 pretty_print : bool, default True
3513 Whether output should be pretty printed with indentation and
3514 line breaks.
3515 parser : {{'lxml','etree'}}, default 'lxml'
3516 Parser module to use for building of tree. Only 'lxml' and
3517 'etree' are supported. With 'lxml', the ability to use XSLT
3518 stylesheet is supported.
3519 stylesheet : str, path object or file-like object, optional
3520 A URL, file-like object, or a raw string containing an XSLT
3521 script used to transform the raw XML output. Script should use
3522 layout of elements and attributes from original output. This
3523 argument requires ``lxml`` to be installed. Only XSLT 1.0
3524 scripts and not later versions is currently supported.
3525 {compression_options}
3526
3527 .. versionchanged:: 1.4.0 Zstandard support.
3528
3529 {storage_options}
3530
3531 Returns
3532 -------
3533 None or str
3534 If ``io`` is None, returns the resulting XML format as a
3535 string. Otherwise returns None.
3536
3537 See Also
3538 --------
3539 to_json : Convert the pandas object to a JSON string.
3540 to_html : Convert DataFrame to a html.
3541
3542 Examples
3543 --------
3544 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({{'shape': ['square', 'circle', 'triangle'],
3545 ... 'degrees': [360, 360, 180],
3546 ... 'sides': [4, np.nan, 3]}})
3547
3548 >>> df.to_xml() # doctest: +SKIP
3549 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
3550 <data>
3551 <row>
3552 <index>0</index>
3553 <shape>square</shape>
3554 <degrees>360</degrees>
3555 <sides>4.0</sides>
3556 </row>
3557 <row>
3558 <index>1</index>
3559 <shape>circle</shape>
3560 <degrees>360</degrees>
3561 <sides/>
3562 </row>
3563 <row>
3564 <index>2</index>
3565 <shape>triangle</shape>
3566 <degrees>180</degrees>
3567 <sides>3.0</sides>
3568 </row>
3569 </data>
3570
3571 >>> df.to_xml(attr_cols=[
3572 ... 'index', 'shape', 'degrees', 'sides'
3573 ... ]) # doctest: +SKIP
3574 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
3575 <data>
3576 <row index="0" shape="square" degrees="360" sides="4.0"/>
3577 <row index="1" shape="circle" degrees="360"/>
3578 <row index="2" shape="triangle" degrees="180" sides="3.0"/>
3579 </data>
3580
3581 >>> df.to_xml(namespaces={{"doc": "https://example.com"}},
3582 ... prefix="doc") # doctest: +SKIP
3583 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
3584 <doc:data xmlns:doc="https://example.com">
3585 <doc:row>
3586 <doc:index>0</doc:index>
3587 <doc:shape>square</doc:shape>
3588 <doc:degrees>360</doc:degrees>
3589 <doc:sides>4.0</doc:sides>
3590 </doc:row>
3591 <doc:row>
3592 <doc:index>1</doc:index>
3593 <doc:shape>circle</doc:shape>
3594 <doc:degrees>360</doc:degrees>
3595 <doc:sides/>
3596 </doc:row>
3597 <doc:row>
3598 <doc:index>2</doc:index>
3599 <doc:shape>triangle</doc:shape>
3600 <doc:degrees>180</doc:degrees>
3601 <doc:sides>3.0</doc:sides>
3602 </doc:row>
3603 </doc:data>
3604 """
3605
3606 from pandas.io.formats.xml import (
3607 EtreeXMLFormatter,
3608 LxmlXMLFormatter,
3609 )
3610
3611 lxml = import_optional_dependency("lxml.etree", errors="ignore")
3612
3613 TreeBuilder: type[EtreeXMLFormatter | LxmlXMLFormatter]
3614
3615 if parser == "lxml":
3616 if lxml is not None:
3617 TreeBuilder = LxmlXMLFormatter
3618 else:
3619 raise ImportError(
3620 "lxml not found, please install or use the etree parser."
3621 )
3622
3623 elif parser == "etree":
3624 TreeBuilder = EtreeXMLFormatter
3625
3626 else:
3627 raise ValueError("Values for parser can only be lxml or etree.")
3628
3629 xml_formatter = TreeBuilder(
3630 self,
3631 path_or_buffer=path_or_buffer,
3632 index=index,
3633 root_name=root_name,
3634 row_name=row_name,
3635 na_rep=na_rep,
3636 attr_cols=attr_cols,
3637 elem_cols=elem_cols,
3638 namespaces=namespaces,
3639 prefix=prefix,
3640 encoding=encoding,
3641 xml_declaration=xml_declaration,
3642 pretty_print=pretty_print,
3643 stylesheet=stylesheet,
3644 compression=compression,
3645 storage_options=storage_options,
3646 )
3647
3648 return xml_formatter.write_output()
3649
3650 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
3651 @doc(INFO_DOCSTRING, **frame_sub_kwargs)
3652 def info(
3653 self,
3654 verbose: bool | None = None,
3655 buf: WriteBuffer[str] | None = None,
3656 max_cols: int | None = None,
3657 memory_usage: bool | str | None = None,
3658 show_counts: bool | None = None,
3659 ) -> None:
3660 info = DataFrameInfo(
3661 data=self,
3662 memory_usage=memory_usage,
3663 )
3664 info.render(
3665 buf=buf,
3666 max_cols=max_cols,
3667 verbose=verbose,
3668 show_counts=show_counts,
3669 )
3670
3671 def memory_usage(self, index: bool = True, deep: bool = False) -> Series:
3672 """
3673 Return the memory usage of each column in bytes.
3674
3675 The memory usage can optionally include the contribution of
3676 the index and elements of `object` dtype.
3677
3678 This value is displayed in `DataFrame.info` by default. This can be
3679 suppressed by setting ``pandas.options.display.memory_usage`` to False.
3680
3681 Parameters
3682 ----------
3683 index : bool, default True
3684 Specifies whether to include the memory usage of the DataFrame's
3685 index in returned Series. If ``index=True``, the memory usage of
3686 the index is the first item in the output.
3687 deep : bool, default False
3688 If True, introspect the data deeply by interrogating
3689 `object` dtypes for system-level memory consumption, and include
3690 it in the returned values.
3691
3692 Returns
3693 -------
3694 Series
3695 A Series whose index is the original column names and whose values
3696 is the memory usage of each column in bytes.
3697
3698 See Also
3699 --------
3700 numpy.ndarray.nbytes : Total bytes consumed by the elements of an
3701 ndarray.
3702 Series.memory_usage : Bytes consumed by a Series.
3703 Categorical : Memory-efficient array for string values with
3704 many repeated values.
3705 DataFrame.info : Concise summary of a DataFrame.
3706
3707 Notes
3708 -----
3709 See the :ref:`Frequently Asked Questions <df-memory-usage>` for more
3710 details.
3711
3712 Examples
3713 --------
3714 >>> dtypes = ['int64', 'float64', 'complex128', 'object', 'bool']
3715 >>> data = dict([(t, np.ones(shape=5000, dtype=int).astype(t))
3716 ... for t in dtypes])
3717 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data)
3718 >>> df.head()
3719 int64 float64 complex128 object bool
3720 0 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3721 1 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3722 2 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3723 3 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3724 4 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3725
3726 >>> df.memory_usage()
3727 Index 128
3728 int64 40000
3729 float64 40000
3730 complex128 80000
3731 object 40000
3732 bool 5000
3733 dtype: int64
3734
3735 >>> df.memory_usage(index=False)
3736 int64 40000
3737 float64 40000
3738 complex128 80000
3739 object 40000
3740 bool 5000
3741 dtype: int64
3742
3743 The memory footprint of `object` dtype columns is ignored by default:
3744
3745 >>> df.memory_usage(deep=True)
3746 Index 128
3747 int64 40000
3748 float64 40000
3749 complex128 80000
3750 object 180000
3751 bool 5000
3752 dtype: int64
3753
3754 Use a Categorical for efficient storage of an object-dtype column with
3755 many repeated values.
3756
3757 >>> df['object'].astype('category').memory_usage(deep=True)
3758 5244
3759 """
3760 result = self._constructor_sliced(
3761 [c.memory_usage(index=False, deep=deep) for col, c in self.items()],
3762 index=self.columns,
3763 dtype=np.intp,
3764 )
3765 if index:
3766 index_memory_usage = self._constructor_sliced(
3767 self.index.memory_usage(deep=deep), index=["Index"]
3768 )
3769 result = index_memory_usage._append(result)
3770 return result
3771
3772 def transpose(self, *args, copy: bool = False) -> DataFrame:
3773 """
3774 Transpose index and columns.
3775
3776 Reflect the DataFrame over its main diagonal by writing rows as columns
3777 and vice-versa. The property :attr:`.T` is an accessor to the method
3778 :meth:`transpose`.
3779
3780 Parameters
3781 ----------
3782 *args : tuple, optional
3783 Accepted for compatibility with NumPy.
3784 copy : bool, default False
3785 Whether to copy the data after transposing, even for DataFrames
3786 with a single dtype.
3787
3788 Note that a copy is always required for mixed dtype DataFrames,
3789 or for DataFrames with any extension types.
3790
3791 .. note::
3792 The `copy` keyword will change behavior in pandas 3.0.
3793 `Copy-on-Write
3794 <https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/user_guide/copy_on_write.html>`__
3795 will be enabled by default, which means that all methods with a
3796 `copy` keyword will use a lazy copy mechanism to defer the copy and
3797 ignore the `copy` keyword. The `copy` keyword will be removed in a
3798 future version of pandas.
3799
3800 You can already get the future behavior and improvements through
3801 enabling copy on write ``pd.options.mode.copy_on_write = True``
3802
3803 Returns
3804 -------
3805 DataFrame
3806 The transposed DataFrame.
3807
3808 See Also
3809 --------
3810 numpy.transpose : Permute the dimensions of a given array.
3811
3812 Notes
3813 -----
3814 Transposing a DataFrame with mixed dtypes will result in a homogeneous
3815 DataFrame with the `object` dtype. In such a case, a copy of the data
3816 is always made.
3817
3818 Examples
3819 --------
3820 **Square DataFrame with homogeneous dtype**
3821
3822 >>> d1 = {'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]}
3823 >>> df1 = pd.DataFrame(data=d1)
3824 >>> df1
3825 col1 col2
3826 0 1 3
3827 1 2 4
3828
3829 >>> df1_transposed = df1.T # or df1.transpose()
3830 >>> df1_transposed
3831 0 1
3832 col1 1 2
3833 col2 3 4
3834
3835 When the dtype is homogeneous in the original DataFrame, we get a
3836 transposed DataFrame with the same dtype:
3837
3838 >>> df1.dtypes
3839 col1 int64
3840 col2 int64
3841 dtype: object
3842 >>> df1_transposed.dtypes
3843 0 int64
3844 1 int64
3845 dtype: object
3846
3847 **Non-square DataFrame with mixed dtypes**
3848
3849 >>> d2 = {'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'],
3850 ... 'score': [9.5, 8],
3851 ... 'employed': [False, True],
3852 ... 'kids': [0, 0]}
3853 >>> df2 = pd.DataFrame(data=d2)
3854 >>> df2
3855 name score employed kids
3856 0 Alice 9.5 False 0
3857 1 Bob 8.0 True 0
3858
3859 >>> df2_transposed = df2.T # or df2.transpose()
3860 >>> df2_transposed
3861 0 1
3862 name Alice Bob
3863 score 9.5 8.0
3864 employed False True
3865 kids 0 0
3866
3867 When the DataFrame has mixed dtypes, we get a transposed DataFrame with
3868 the `object` dtype:
3869
3870 >>> df2.dtypes
3871 name object
3872 score float64
3873 employed bool
3874 kids int64
3875 dtype: object
3876 >>> df2_transposed.dtypes
3877 0 object
3878 1 object
3879 dtype: object
3880 """
3881 nv.validate_transpose(args, {})
3882 # construct the args
3883
3884 dtypes = list(self.dtypes)
3885
3886 if self._can_fast_transpose:
3887 # Note: tests pass without this, but this improves perf quite a bit.
3888 new_vals = self._values.T
3889 if copy and not using_copy_on_write():
3890 new_vals = new_vals.copy()
3891
3892 result = self._constructor(
3893 new_vals,
3894 index=self.columns,
3895 columns=self.index,
3896 copy=False,
3897 dtype=new_vals.dtype,
3898 )
3899 if using_copy_on_write() and len(self) > 0:
3900 result._mgr.add_references(self._mgr) # type: ignore[arg-type]
3901
3902 elif (
3903 self._is_homogeneous_type
3904 and dtypes
3905 and isinstance(dtypes[0], ExtensionDtype)
3906 ):
3907 new_values: list
3908 if isinstance(dtypes[0], BaseMaskedDtype):
3909 # We have masked arrays with the same dtype. We can transpose faster.
3910 from pandas.core.arrays.masked import (
3911 transpose_homogeneous_masked_arrays,
3912 )
3913
3914 new_values = transpose_homogeneous_masked_arrays(
3915 cast(Sequence[BaseMaskedArray], self._iter_column_arrays())
3916 )
3917 elif isinstance(dtypes[0], ArrowDtype):
3918 # We have arrow EAs with the same dtype. We can transpose faster.
3919 from pandas.core.arrays.arrow.array import (
3920 ArrowExtensionArray,
3921 transpose_homogeneous_pyarrow,
3922 )
3923
3924 new_values = transpose_homogeneous_pyarrow(
3925 cast(Sequence[ArrowExtensionArray], self._iter_column_arrays())
3926 )
3927 else:
3928 # We have other EAs with the same dtype. We preserve dtype in transpose.
3929 dtyp = dtypes[0]
3930 arr_typ = dtyp.construct_array_type()
3931 values = self.values
3932 new_values = [arr_typ._from_sequence(row, dtype=dtyp) for row in values]
3933
3934 result = type(self)._from_arrays(
3935 new_values,
3936 index=self.columns,
3937 columns=self.index,
3938 verify_integrity=False,
3939 )
3940
3941 else:
3942 new_arr = self.values.T
3943 if copy and not using_copy_on_write():
3944 new_arr = new_arr.copy()
3945 result = self._constructor(
3946 new_arr,
3947 index=self.columns,
3948 columns=self.index,
3949 dtype=new_arr.dtype,
3950 # We already made a copy (more than one block)
3951 copy=False,
3952 )
3953
3954 return result.__finalize__(self, method="transpose")
3955
3956 @property
3957 def T(self) -> DataFrame:
3958 """
3959 The transpose of the DataFrame.
3960
3961 Returns
3962 -------
3963 DataFrame
3964 The transposed DataFrame.
3965
3966 See Also
3967 --------
3968 DataFrame.transpose : Transpose index and columns.
3969
3970 Examples
3971 --------
3972 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]})
3973 >>> df
3974 col1 col2
3975 0 1 3
3976 1 2 4
3977
3978 >>> df.T
3979 0 1
3980 col1 1 2
3981 col2 3 4
3982 """
3983 return self.transpose()
3984
3985 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
3986 # Indexing Methods
3987
3988 def _ixs(self, i: int, axis: AxisInt = 0) -> Series:
3989 """
3990 Parameters
3991 ----------
3992 i : int
3993 axis : int
3994
3995 Returns
3996 -------
3997 Series
3998 """
3999 # irow
4000 if axis == 0:
4001 new_mgr = self._mgr.fast_xs(i)
4002
4003 # if we are a copy, mark as such
4004 copy = isinstance(new_mgr.array, np.ndarray) and new_mgr.array.base is None
4005 result = self._constructor_sliced_from_mgr(new_mgr, axes=new_mgr.axes)
4006 result._name = self.index[i]
4007 result = result.__finalize__(self)
4008 result._set_is_copy(self, copy=copy)
4009 return result
4010
4011 # icol
4012 else:
4013 label = self.columns[i]
4014
4015 col_mgr = self._mgr.iget(i)
4016 result = self._box_col_values(col_mgr, i)
4017
4018 # this is a cached value, mark it so
4019 result._set_as_cached(label, self)
4020 return result
4021
4022 def _get_column_array(self, i: int) -> ArrayLike:
4023 """
4024 Get the values of the i'th column (ndarray or ExtensionArray, as stored
4025 in the Block)
4026
4027 Warning! The returned array is a view but doesn't handle Copy-on-Write,
4028 so this should be used with caution (for read-only purposes).
4029 """
4030 return self._mgr.iget_values(i)
4031
4032 def _iter_column_arrays(self) -> Iterator[ArrayLike]:
4033 """
4034 Iterate over the arrays of all columns in order.
4035 This returns the values as stored in the Block (ndarray or ExtensionArray).
4036
4037 Warning! The returned array is a view but doesn't handle Copy-on-Write,
4038 so this should be used with caution (for read-only purposes).
4039 """
4040 if isinstance(self._mgr, ArrayManager):
4041 yield from self._mgr.arrays
4042 else:
4043 for i in range(len(self.columns)):
4044 yield self._get_column_array(i)
4045
4046 def _getitem_nocopy(self, key: list):
4047 """
4048 Behaves like __getitem__, but returns a view in cases where __getitem__
4049 would make a copy.
4050 """
4051 # TODO(CoW): can be removed if/when we are always Copy-on-Write
4052 indexer = self.columns._get_indexer_strict(key, "columns")[1]
4053 new_axis = self.columns[indexer]
4054
4055 new_mgr = self._mgr.reindex_indexer(
4056 new_axis,
4057 indexer,
4058 axis=0,
4059 allow_dups=True,
4060 copy=False,
4061 only_slice=True,
4062 )
4063 result = self._constructor_from_mgr(new_mgr, axes=new_mgr.axes)
4064 result = result.__finalize__(self)
4065 return result
4066
4067 def __getitem__(self, key):
4068 check_dict_or_set_indexers(key)
4069 key = lib.item_from_zerodim(key)
4070 key = com.apply_if_callable(key, self)
4071
4072 if is_hashable(key) and not is_iterator(key):
4073 # is_iterator to exclude generator e.g. test_getitem_listlike
4074 # shortcut if the key is in columns
4075 is_mi = isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex)
4076 # GH#45316 Return view if key is not duplicated
4077 # Only use drop_duplicates with duplicates for performance
4078 if not is_mi and (
4079 self.columns.is_unique
4080 and key in self.columns
4081 or key in self.columns.drop_duplicates(keep=False)
4082 ):
4083 return self._get_item_cache(key)
4084
4085 elif is_mi and self.columns.is_unique and key in self.columns:
4086 return self._getitem_multilevel(key)
4087
4088 # Do we have a slicer (on rows)?
4089 if isinstance(key, slice):
4090 return self._getitem_slice(key)
4091
4092 # Do we have a (boolean) DataFrame?
4093 if isinstance(key, DataFrame):
4094 return self.where(key)
4095
4096 # Do we have a (boolean) 1d indexer?
4097 if com.is_bool_indexer(key):
4098 return self._getitem_bool_array(key)
4099
4100 # We are left with two options: a single key, and a collection of keys,
4101 # We interpret tuples as collections only for non-MultiIndex
4102 is_single_key = isinstance(key, tuple) or not is_list_like(key)
4103
4104 if is_single_key:
4105 if self.columns.nlevels > 1:
4106 return self._getitem_multilevel(key)
4107 indexer = self.columns.get_loc(key)
4108 if is_integer(indexer):
4109 indexer = [indexer]
4110 else:
4111 if is_iterator(key):
4112 key = list(key)
4113 indexer = self.columns._get_indexer_strict(key, "columns")[1]
4114
4115 # take() does not accept boolean indexers
4116 if getattr(indexer, "dtype", None) == bool:
4117 indexer = np.where(indexer)[0]
4118
4119 if isinstance(indexer, slice):
4120 return self._slice(indexer, axis=1)
4121
4122 data = self._take_with_is_copy(indexer, axis=1)
4123
4124 if is_single_key:
4125 # What does looking for a single key in a non-unique index return?
4126 # The behavior is inconsistent. It returns a Series, except when
4127 # - the key itself is repeated (test on data.shape, #9519), or
4128 # - we have a MultiIndex on columns (test on self.columns, #21309)
4129 if data.shape[1] == 1 and not isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex):
4130 # GH#26490 using data[key] can cause RecursionError
4131 return data._get_item_cache(key)
4132
4133 return data
4134
4135 def _getitem_bool_array(self, key):
4136 # also raises Exception if object array with NA values
4137 # warning here just in case -- previously __setitem__ was
4138 # reindexing but __getitem__ was not; it seems more reasonable to
4139 # go with the __setitem__ behavior since that is more consistent
4140 # with all other indexing behavior
4141 if isinstance(key, Series) and not key.index.equals(self.index):
4142 warnings.warn(
4143 "Boolean Series key will be reindexed to match DataFrame index.",
4144 UserWarning,
4145 stacklevel=find_stack_level(),
4146 )
4147 elif len(key) != len(self.index):
4148 raise ValueError(
4149 f"Item wrong length {len(key)} instead of {len(self.index)}."
4150 )
4151
4152 # check_bool_indexer will throw exception if Series key cannot
4153 # be reindexed to match DataFrame rows
4154 key = check_bool_indexer(self.index, key)
4155
4156 if key.all():
4157 return self.copy(deep=None)
4158
4159 indexer = key.nonzero()[0]
4160 return self._take_with_is_copy(indexer, axis=0)
4161
4162 def _getitem_multilevel(self, key):
4163 # self.columns is a MultiIndex
4164 loc = self.columns.get_loc(key)
4165 if isinstance(loc, (slice, np.ndarray)):
4166 new_columns = self.columns[loc]
4167 result_columns = maybe_droplevels(new_columns, key)
4168 result = self.iloc[:, loc]
4169 result.columns = result_columns
4170
4171 # If there is only one column being returned, and its name is
4172 # either an empty string, or a tuple with an empty string as its
4173 # first element, then treat the empty string as a placeholder
4174 # and return the column as if the user had provided that empty
4175 # string in the key. If the result is a Series, exclude the
4176 # implied empty string from its name.
4177 if len(result.columns) == 1:
4178 # e.g. test_frame_getitem_multicolumn_empty_level,
4179 # test_frame_mixed_depth_get, test_loc_setitem_single_column_slice
4180 top = result.columns[0]
4181 if isinstance(top, tuple):
4182 top = top[0]
4183 if top == "":
4184 result = result[""]
4185 if isinstance(result, Series):
4186 result = self._constructor_sliced(
4187 result, index=self.index, name=key
4188 )
4189
4190 result._set_is_copy(self)
4191 return result
4192 else:
4193 # loc is neither a slice nor ndarray, so must be an int
4194 return self._ixs(loc, axis=1)
4195
4196 def _get_value(self, index, col, takeable: bool = False) -> Scalar:
4197 """
4198 Quickly retrieve single value at passed column and index.
4199
4200 Parameters
4201 ----------
4202 index : row label
4203 col : column label
4204 takeable : interpret the index/col as indexers, default False
4205
4206 Returns
4207 -------
4208 scalar
4209
4210 Notes
4211 -----
4212 Assumes that both `self.index._index_as_unique` and
4213 `self.columns._index_as_unique`; Caller is responsible for checking.
4214 """
4215 if takeable:
4216 series = self._ixs(col, axis=1)
4217 return series._values[index]
4218
4219 series = self._get_item_cache(col)
4220 engine = self.index._engine
4221
4222 if not isinstance(self.index, MultiIndex):
4223 # CategoricalIndex: Trying to use the engine fastpath may give incorrect
4224 # results if our categories are integers that dont match our codes
4225 # IntervalIndex: IntervalTree has no get_loc
4226 row = self.index.get_loc(index)
4227 return series._values[row]
4228
4229 # For MultiIndex going through engine effectively restricts us to
4230 # same-length tuples; see test_get_set_value_no_partial_indexing
4231 loc = engine.get_loc(index)
4232 return series._values[loc]
4233
4234 def isetitem(self, loc, value) -> None:
4235 """
4236 Set the given value in the column with position `loc`.
4237
4238 This is a positional analogue to ``__setitem__``.
4239
4240 Parameters
4241 ----------
4242 loc : int or sequence of ints
4243 Index position for the column.
4244 value : scalar or arraylike
4245 Value(s) for the column.
4246
4247 Notes
4248 -----
4249 ``frame.isetitem(loc, value)`` is an in-place method as it will
4250 modify the DataFrame in place (not returning a new object). In contrast to
4251 ``frame.iloc[:, i] = value`` which will try to update the existing values in
4252 place, ``frame.isetitem(loc, value)`` will not update the values of the column
4253 itself in place, it will instead insert a new array.
4254
4255 In cases where ``frame.columns`` is unique, this is equivalent to
4256 ``frame[frame.columns[i]] = value``.
4257 """
4258 if isinstance(value, DataFrame):
4259 if is_integer(loc):
4260 loc = [loc]
4261
4262 if len(loc) != len(value.columns):
4263 raise ValueError(
4264 f"Got {len(loc)} positions but value has {len(value.columns)} "
4265 f"columns."
4266 )
4267
4268 for i, idx in enumerate(loc):
4269 arraylike, refs = self._sanitize_column(value.iloc[:, i])
4270 self._iset_item_mgr(idx, arraylike, inplace=False, refs=refs)
4271 return
4272
4273 arraylike, refs = self._sanitize_column(value)
4274 self._iset_item_mgr(loc, arraylike, inplace=False, refs=refs)
4275
4276 def __setitem__(self, key, value) -> None:
4277 if not PYPY and using_copy_on_write():
4278 if sys.getrefcount(self) <= 3:
4279 warnings.warn(
4280 _chained_assignment_msg, ChainedAssignmentError, stacklevel=2
4281 )
4282 elif not PYPY and not using_copy_on_write():
4283 if sys.getrefcount(self) <= 3 and (
4284 warn_copy_on_write()
4285 or (
4286 not warn_copy_on_write()
4287 and any(b.refs.has_reference() for b in self._mgr.blocks) # type: ignore[union-attr]
4288 )
4289 ):
4290 warnings.warn(
4291 _chained_assignment_warning_msg, FutureWarning, stacklevel=2
4292 )
4293
4294 key = com.apply_if_callable(key, self)
4295
4296 # see if we can slice the rows
4297 if isinstance(key, slice):
4298 slc = self.index._convert_slice_indexer(key, kind="getitem")
4299 return self._setitem_slice(slc, value)
4300
4301 if isinstance(key, DataFrame) or getattr(key, "ndim", None) == 2:
4302 self._setitem_frame(key, value)
4303 elif isinstance(key, (Series, np.ndarray, list, Index)):
4304 self._setitem_array(key, value)
4305 elif isinstance(value, DataFrame):
4306 self._set_item_frame_value(key, value)
4307 elif (
4308 is_list_like(value)
4309 and not self.columns.is_unique
4310 and 1 < len(self.columns.get_indexer_for([key])) == len(value)
4311 ):
4312 # Column to set is duplicated
4313 self._setitem_array([key], value)
4314 else:
4315 # set column
4316 self._set_item(key, value)
4317
4318 def _setitem_slice(self, key: slice, value) -> None:
4319 # NB: we can't just use self.loc[key] = value because that
4320 # operates on labels and we need to operate positional for
4321 # backwards-compat, xref GH#31469
4322 self._check_setitem_copy()
4323 self.iloc[key] = value
4324
4325 def _setitem_array(self, key, value):
4326 # also raises Exception if object array with NA values
4327 if com.is_bool_indexer(key):
4328 # bool indexer is indexing along rows
4329 if len(key) != len(self.index):
4330 raise ValueError(
4331 f"Item wrong length {len(key)} instead of {len(self.index)}!"
4332 )
4333 key = check_bool_indexer(self.index, key)
4334 indexer = key.nonzero()[0]
4335 self._check_setitem_copy()
4336 if isinstance(value, DataFrame):
4337 # GH#39931 reindex since iloc does not align
4338 value = value.reindex(self.index.take(indexer))
4339 self.iloc[indexer] = value
4340
4341 else:
4342 # Note: unlike self.iloc[:, indexer] = value, this will
4343 # never try to overwrite values inplace
4344
4345 if isinstance(value, DataFrame):
4346 check_key_length(self.columns, key, value)
4347 for k1, k2 in zip(key, value.columns):
4348 self[k1] = value[k2]
4349
4350 elif not is_list_like(value):
4351 for col in key:
4352 self[col] = value
4353
4354 elif isinstance(value, np.ndarray) and value.ndim == 2:
4355 self._iset_not_inplace(key, value)
4356
4357 elif np.ndim(value) > 1:
4358 # list of lists
4359 value = DataFrame(value).values
4360 return self._setitem_array(key, value)
4361
4362 else:
4363 self._iset_not_inplace(key, value)
4364
4365 def _iset_not_inplace(self, key, value):
4366 # GH#39510 when setting with df[key] = obj with a list-like key and
4367 # list-like value, we iterate over those listlikes and set columns
4368 # one at a time. This is different from dispatching to
4369 # `self.loc[:, key]= value` because loc.__setitem__ may overwrite
4370 # data inplace, whereas this will insert new arrays.
4371
4372 def igetitem(obj, i: int):
4373 # Note: we catch DataFrame obj before getting here, but
4374 # hypothetically would return obj.iloc[:, i]
4375 if isinstance(obj, np.ndarray):
4376 return obj[..., i]
4377 else:
4378 return obj[i]
4379
4380 if self.columns.is_unique:
4381 if np.shape(value)[-1] != len(key):
4382 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
4383
4384 for i, col in enumerate(key):
4385 self[col] = igetitem(value, i)
4386
4387 else:
4388 ilocs = self.columns.get_indexer_non_unique(key)[0]
4389 if (ilocs < 0).any():
4390 # key entries not in self.columns
4391 raise NotImplementedError
4392
4393 if np.shape(value)[-1] != len(ilocs):
4394 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
4395
4396 assert np.ndim(value) <= 2
4397
4398 orig_columns = self.columns
4399
4400 # Using self.iloc[:, i] = ... may set values inplace, which
4401 # by convention we do not do in __setitem__
4402 try:
4403 self.columns = Index(range(len(self.columns)))
4404 for i, iloc in enumerate(ilocs):
4405 self[iloc] = igetitem(value, i)
4406 finally:
4407 self.columns = orig_columns
4408
4409 def _setitem_frame(self, key, value):
4410 # support boolean setting with DataFrame input, e.g.
4411 # df[df > df2] = 0
4412 if isinstance(key, np.ndarray):
4413 if key.shape != self.shape:
4414 raise ValueError("Array conditional must be same shape as self")
4415 key = self._constructor(key, **self._construct_axes_dict(), copy=False)
4416
4417 if key.size and not all(is_bool_dtype(dtype) for dtype in key.dtypes):
4418 raise TypeError(
4419 "Must pass DataFrame or 2-d ndarray with boolean values only"
4420 )
4421
4422 self._check_setitem_copy()
4423 self._where(-key, value, inplace=True)
4424
4425 def _set_item_frame_value(self, key, value: DataFrame) -> None:
4426 self._ensure_valid_index(value)
4427
4428 # align columns
4429 if key in self.columns:
4430 loc = self.columns.get_loc(key)
4431 cols = self.columns[loc]
4432 len_cols = 1 if is_scalar(cols) or isinstance(cols, tuple) else len(cols)
4433 if len_cols != len(value.columns):
4434 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
4435
4436 # align right-hand-side columns if self.columns
4437 # is multi-index and self[key] is a sub-frame
4438 if isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex) and isinstance(
4439 loc, (slice, Series, np.ndarray, Index)
4440 ):
4441 cols_droplevel = maybe_droplevels(cols, key)
4442 if len(cols_droplevel) and not cols_droplevel.equals(value.columns):
4443 value = value.reindex(cols_droplevel, axis=1)
4444
4445 for col, col_droplevel in zip(cols, cols_droplevel):
4446 self[col] = value[col_droplevel]
4447 return
4448
4449 if is_scalar(cols):
4450 self[cols] = value[value.columns[0]]
4451 return
4452
4453 locs: np.ndarray | list
4454 if isinstance(loc, slice):
4455 locs = np.arange(loc.start, loc.stop, loc.step)
4456 elif is_scalar(loc):
4457 locs = [loc]
4458 else:
4459 locs = loc.nonzero()[0]
4460
4461 return self.isetitem(locs, value)
4462
4463 if len(value.columns) > 1:
4464 raise ValueError(
4465 "Cannot set a DataFrame with multiple columns to the single "
4466 f"column {key}"
4467 )
4468 elif len(value.columns) == 0:
4469 raise ValueError(
4470 f"Cannot set a DataFrame without columns to the column {key}"
4471 )
4472
4473 self[key] = value[value.columns[0]]
4474
4475 def _iset_item_mgr(
4476 self,
4477 loc: int | slice | np.ndarray,
4478 value,
4479 inplace: bool = False,
4480 refs: BlockValuesRefs | None = None,
4481 ) -> None:
4482 # when called from _set_item_mgr loc can be anything returned from get_loc
4483 self._mgr.iset(loc, value, inplace=inplace, refs=refs)
4484 self._clear_item_cache()
4485
4486 def _set_item_mgr(
4487 self, key, value: ArrayLike, refs: BlockValuesRefs | None = None
4488 ) -> None:
4489 try:
4490 loc = self._info_axis.get_loc(key)
4491 except KeyError:
4492 # This item wasn't present, just insert at end
4493 self._mgr.insert(len(self._info_axis), key, value, refs)
4494 else:
4495 self._iset_item_mgr(loc, value, refs=refs)
4496
4497 # check if we are modifying a copy
4498 # try to set first as we want an invalid
4499 # value exception to occur first
4500 if len(self):
4501 self._check_setitem_copy()
4502
4503 def _iset_item(self, loc: int, value: Series, inplace: bool = True) -> None:
4504 # We are only called from _replace_columnwise which guarantees that
4505 # no reindex is necessary
4506 if using_copy_on_write():
4507 self._iset_item_mgr(
4508 loc, value._values, inplace=inplace, refs=value._references
4509 )
4510 else:
4511 self._iset_item_mgr(loc, value._values.copy(), inplace=True)
4512
4513 # check if we are modifying a copy
4514 # try to set first as we want an invalid
4515 # value exception to occur first
4516 if len(self):
4517 self._check_setitem_copy()
4518
4519 def _set_item(self, key, value) -> None:
4520 """
4521 Add series to DataFrame in specified column.
4522
4523 If series is a numpy-array (not a Series/TimeSeries), it must be the
4524 same length as the DataFrames index or an error will be thrown.
4525
4526 Series/TimeSeries will be conformed to the DataFrames index to
4527 ensure homogeneity.
4528 """
4529 value, refs = self._sanitize_column(value)
4530
4531 if (
4532 key in self.columns
4533 and value.ndim == 1
4534 and not isinstance(value.dtype, ExtensionDtype)
4535 ):
4536 # broadcast across multiple columns if necessary
4537 if not self.columns.is_unique or isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex):
4538 existing_piece = self[key]
4539 if isinstance(existing_piece, DataFrame):
4540 value = np.tile(value, (len(existing_piece.columns), 1)).T
4541 refs = None
4542
4543 self._set_item_mgr(key, value, refs)
4544
4545 def _set_value(
4546 self, index: IndexLabel, col, value: Scalar, takeable: bool = False
4547 ) -> None:
4548 """
4549 Put single value at passed column and index.
4550
4551 Parameters
4552 ----------
4553 index : Label
4554 row label
4555 col : Label
4556 column label
4557 value : scalar
4558 takeable : bool, default False
4559 Sets whether or not index/col interpreted as indexers
4560 """
4561 try:
4562 if takeable:
4563 icol = col
4564 iindex = cast(int, index)
4565 else:
4566 icol = self.columns.get_loc(col)
4567 iindex = self.index.get_loc(index)
4568 self._mgr.column_setitem(icol, iindex, value, inplace_only=True)
4569 self._clear_item_cache()
4570
4571 except (KeyError, TypeError, ValueError, LossySetitemError):
4572 # get_loc might raise a KeyError for missing labels (falling back
4573 # to (i)loc will do expansion of the index)
4574 # column_setitem will do validation that may raise TypeError,
4575 # ValueError, or LossySetitemError
4576 # set using a non-recursive method & reset the cache
4577 if takeable:
4578 self.iloc[index, col] = value
4579 else:
4580 self.loc[index, col] = value
4581 self._item_cache.pop(col, None)
4582
4583 except InvalidIndexError as ii_err:
4584 # GH48729: Seems like you are trying to assign a value to a
4585 # row when only scalar options are permitted
4586 raise InvalidIndexError(
4587 f"You can only assign a scalar value not a {type(value)}"
4588 ) from ii_err
4589
4590 def _ensure_valid_index(self, value) -> None:
4591 """
4592 Ensure that if we don't have an index, that we can create one from the
4593 passed value.
4594 """
4595 # GH5632, make sure that we are a Series convertible
4596 if not len(self.index) and is_list_like(value) and len(value):
4597 if not isinstance(value, DataFrame):
4598 try:
4599 value = Series(value)
4600 except (ValueError, NotImplementedError, TypeError) as err:
4601 raise ValueError(
4602 "Cannot set a frame with no defined index "
4603 "and a value that cannot be converted to a Series"
4604 ) from err
4605
4606 # GH31368 preserve name of index
4607 index_copy = value.index.copy()
4608 if self.index.name is not None:
4609 index_copy.name = self.index.name
4610
4611 self._mgr = self._mgr.reindex_axis(index_copy, axis=1, fill_value=np.nan)
4612
4613 def _box_col_values(self, values: SingleDataManager, loc: int) -> Series:
4614 """
4615 Provide boxed values for a column.
4616 """
4617 # Lookup in columns so that if e.g. a str datetime was passed
4618 # we attach the Timestamp object as the name.
4619 name = self.columns[loc]
4620 # We get index=self.index bc values is a SingleDataManager
4621 obj = self._constructor_sliced_from_mgr(values, axes=values.axes)
4622 obj._name = name
4623 return obj.__finalize__(self)
4624
4625 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
4626 # Lookup Caching
4627
4628 def _clear_item_cache(self) -> None:
4629 self._item_cache.clear()
4630
4631 def _get_item_cache(self, item: Hashable) -> Series:
4632 """Return the cached item, item represents a label indexer."""
4633 if using_copy_on_write() or warn_copy_on_write():
4634 loc = self.columns.get_loc(item)
4635 return self._ixs(loc, axis=1)
4636
4637 cache = self._item_cache
4638 res = cache.get(item)
4639 if res is None:
4640 # All places that call _get_item_cache have unique columns,
4641 # pending resolution of GH#33047
4642
4643 loc = self.columns.get_loc(item)
4644 res = self._ixs(loc, axis=1)
4645
4646 cache[item] = res
4647
4648 # for a chain
4649 res._is_copy = self._is_copy
4650 return res
4651
4652 def _reset_cacher(self) -> None:
4653 # no-op for DataFrame
4654 pass
4655
4656 def _maybe_cache_changed(self, item, value: Series, inplace: bool) -> None:
4657 """
4658 The object has called back to us saying maybe it has changed.
4659 """
4660 loc = self._info_axis.get_loc(item)
4661 arraylike = value._values
4662
4663 old = self._ixs(loc, axis=1)
4664 if old._values is value._values and inplace:
4665 # GH#46149 avoid making unnecessary copies/block-splitting
4666 return
4667
4668 self._mgr.iset(loc, arraylike, inplace=inplace)
4669
4670 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
4671 # Unsorted
4672
4673 @overload
4674 def query(self, expr: str, *, inplace: Literal[False] = ..., **kwargs) -> DataFrame:
4675 ...
4676
4677 @overload
4678 def query(self, expr: str, *, inplace: Literal[True], **kwargs) -> None:
4679 ...
4680
4681 @overload
4682 def query(self, expr: str, *, inplace: bool = ..., **kwargs) -> DataFrame | None:
4683 ...
4684
4685 def query(self, expr: str, *, inplace: bool = False, **kwargs) -> DataFrame | None:
4686 """
4687 Query the columns of a DataFrame with a boolean expression.
4688
4689 Parameters
4690 ----------
4691 expr : str
4692 The query string to evaluate.
4693
4694 You can refer to variables
4695 in the environment by prefixing them with an '@' character like
4696 ``@a + b``.
4697
4698 You can refer to column names that are not valid Python variable names
4699 by surrounding them in backticks. Thus, column names containing spaces
4700 or punctuations (besides underscores) or starting with digits must be
4701 surrounded by backticks. (For example, a column named "Area (cm^2)" would
4702 be referenced as ```Area (cm^2)```). Column names which are Python keywords
4703 (like "list", "for", "import", etc) cannot be used.
4704
4705 For example, if one of your columns is called ``a a`` and you want
4706 to sum it with ``b``, your query should be ```a a` + b``.
4707
4708 inplace : bool
4709 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
4710 **kwargs
4711 See the documentation for :func:`eval` for complete details
4712 on the keyword arguments accepted by :meth:`DataFrame.query`.
4713
4714 Returns
4715 -------
4716 DataFrame or None
4717 DataFrame resulting from the provided query expression or
4718 None if ``inplace=True``.
4719
4720 See Also
4721 --------
4722 eval : Evaluate a string describing operations on
4723 DataFrame columns.
4724 DataFrame.eval : Evaluate a string describing operations on
4725 DataFrame columns.
4726
4727 Notes
4728 -----
4729 The result of the evaluation of this expression is first passed to
4730 :attr:`DataFrame.loc` and if that fails because of a
4731 multidimensional key (e.g., a DataFrame) then the result will be passed
4732 to :meth:`DataFrame.__getitem__`.
4733
4734 This method uses the top-level :func:`eval` function to
4735 evaluate the passed query.
4736
4737 The :meth:`~pandas.DataFrame.query` method uses a slightly
4738 modified Python syntax by default. For example, the ``&`` and ``|``
4739 (bitwise) operators have the precedence of their boolean cousins,
4740 :keyword:`and` and :keyword:`or`. This *is* syntactically valid Python,
4741 however the semantics are different.
4742
4743 You can change the semantics of the expression by passing the keyword
4744 argument ``parser='python'``. This enforces the same semantics as
4745 evaluation in Python space. Likewise, you can pass ``engine='python'``
4746 to evaluate an expression using Python itself as a backend. This is not
4747 recommended as it is inefficient compared to using ``numexpr`` as the
4748 engine.
4749
4750 The :attr:`DataFrame.index` and
4751 :attr:`DataFrame.columns` attributes of the
4752 :class:`~pandas.DataFrame` instance are placed in the query namespace
4753 by default, which allows you to treat both the index and columns of the
4754 frame as a column in the frame.
4755 The identifier ``index`` is used for the frame index; you can also
4756 use the name of the index to identify it in a query. Please note that
4757 Python keywords may not be used as identifiers.
4758
4759 For further details and examples see the ``query`` documentation in
4760 :ref:`indexing <indexing.query>`.
4761
4762 *Backtick quoted variables*
4763
4764 Backtick quoted variables are parsed as literal Python code and
4765 are converted internally to a Python valid identifier.
4766 This can lead to the following problems.
4767
4768 During parsing a number of disallowed characters inside the backtick
4769 quoted string are replaced by strings that are allowed as a Python identifier.
4770 These characters include all operators in Python, the space character, the
4771 question mark, the exclamation mark, the dollar sign, and the euro sign.
4772 For other characters that fall outside the ASCII range (U+0001..U+007F)
4773 and those that are not further specified in PEP 3131,
4774 the query parser will raise an error.
4775 This excludes whitespace different than the space character,
4776 but also the hashtag (as it is used for comments) and the backtick
4777 itself (backtick can also not be escaped).
4778
4779 In a special case, quotes that make a pair around a backtick can
4780 confuse the parser.
4781 For example, ```it's` > `that's``` will raise an error,
4782 as it forms a quoted string (``'s > `that'``) with a backtick inside.
4783
4784 See also the Python documentation about lexical analysis
4785 (https://docs.python.org/3/reference/lexical_analysis.html)
4786 in combination with the source code in :mod:`pandas.core.computation.parsing`.
4787
4788 Examples
4789 --------
4790 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': range(1, 6),
4791 ... 'B': range(10, 0, -2),
4792 ... 'C C': range(10, 5, -1)})
4793 >>> df
4794 A B C C
4795 0 1 10 10
4796 1 2 8 9
4797 2 3 6 8
4798 3 4 4 7
4799 4 5 2 6
4800 >>> df.query('A > B')
4801 A B C C
4802 4 5 2 6
4803
4804 The previous expression is equivalent to
4805
4806 >>> df[df.A > df.B]
4807 A B C C
4808 4 5 2 6
4809
4810 For columns with spaces in their name, you can use backtick quoting.
4811
4812 >>> df.query('B == `C C`')
4813 A B C C
4814 0 1 10 10
4815
4816 The previous expression is equivalent to
4817
4818 >>> df[df.B == df['C C']]
4819 A B C C
4820 0 1 10 10
4821 """
4822 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
4823 if not isinstance(expr, str):
4824 msg = f"expr must be a string to be evaluated, {type(expr)} given"
4825 raise ValueError(msg)
4826 kwargs["level"] = kwargs.pop("level", 0) + 1
4827 kwargs["target"] = None
4828 res = self.eval(expr, **kwargs)
4829
4830 try:
4831 result = self.loc[res]
4832 except ValueError:
4833 # when res is multi-dimensional loc raises, but this is sometimes a
4834 # valid query
4835 result = self[res]
4836
4837 if inplace:
4838 self._update_inplace(result)
4839 return None
4840 else:
4841 return result
4842
4843 @overload
4844 def eval(self, expr: str, *, inplace: Literal[False] = ..., **kwargs) -> Any:
4845 ...
4846
4847 @overload
4848 def eval(self, expr: str, *, inplace: Literal[True], **kwargs) -> None:
4849 ...
4850
4851 def eval(self, expr: str, *, inplace: bool = False, **kwargs) -> Any | None:
4852 """
4853 Evaluate a string describing operations on DataFrame columns.
4854
4855 Operates on columns only, not specific rows or elements. This allows
4856 `eval` to run arbitrary code, which can make you vulnerable to code
4857 injection if you pass user input to this function.
4858
4859 Parameters
4860 ----------
4861 expr : str
4862 The expression string to evaluate.
4863 inplace : bool, default False
4864 If the expression contains an assignment, whether to perform the
4865 operation inplace and mutate the existing DataFrame. Otherwise,
4866 a new DataFrame is returned.
4867 **kwargs
4868 See the documentation for :func:`eval` for complete details
4869 on the keyword arguments accepted by
4870 :meth:`~pandas.DataFrame.query`.
4871
4872 Returns
4873 -------
4874 ndarray, scalar, pandas object, or None
4875 The result of the evaluation or None if ``inplace=True``.
4876
4877 See Also
4878 --------
4879 DataFrame.query : Evaluates a boolean expression to query the columns
4880 of a frame.
4881 DataFrame.assign : Can evaluate an expression or function to create new
4882 values for a column.
4883 eval : Evaluate a Python expression as a string using various
4884 backends.
4885
4886 Notes
4887 -----
4888 For more details see the API documentation for :func:`~eval`.
4889 For detailed examples see :ref:`enhancing performance with eval
4890 <enhancingperf.eval>`.
4891
4892 Examples
4893 --------
4894 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': range(1, 6), 'B': range(10, 0, -2)})
4895 >>> df
4896 A B
4897 0 1 10
4898 1 2 8
4899 2 3 6
4900 3 4 4
4901 4 5 2
4902 >>> df.eval('A + B')
4903 0 11
4904 1 10
4905 2 9
4906 3 8
4907 4 7
4908 dtype: int64
4909
4910 Assignment is allowed though by default the original DataFrame is not
4911 modified.
4912
4913 >>> df.eval('C = A + B')
4914 A B C
4915 0 1 10 11
4916 1 2 8 10
4917 2 3 6 9
4918 3 4 4 8
4919 4 5 2 7
4920 >>> df
4921 A B
4922 0 1 10
4923 1 2 8
4924 2 3 6
4925 3 4 4
4926 4 5 2
4927
4928 Multiple columns can be assigned to using multi-line expressions:
4929
4930 >>> df.eval(
4931 ... '''
4932 ... C = A + B
4933 ... D = A - B
4934 ... '''
4935 ... )
4936 A B C D
4937 0 1 10 11 -9
4938 1 2 8 10 -6
4939 2 3 6 9 -3
4940 3 4 4 8 0
4941 4 5 2 7 3
4942 """
4943 from pandas.core.computation.eval import eval as _eval
4944
4945 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
4946 kwargs["level"] = kwargs.pop("level", 0) + 1
4947 index_resolvers = self._get_index_resolvers()
4948 column_resolvers = self._get_cleaned_column_resolvers()
4949 resolvers = column_resolvers, index_resolvers
4950 if "target" not in kwargs:
4951 kwargs["target"] = self
4952 kwargs["resolvers"] = tuple(kwargs.get("resolvers", ())) + resolvers
4953
4954 return _eval(expr, inplace=inplace, **kwargs)
4955
4956 def select_dtypes(self, include=None, exclude=None) -> Self:
4957 """
4958 Return a subset of the DataFrame's columns based on the column dtypes.
4959
4960 Parameters
4961 ----------
4962 include, exclude : scalar or list-like
4963 A selection of dtypes or strings to be included/excluded. At least
4964 one of these parameters must be supplied.
4965
4966 Returns
4967 -------
4968 DataFrame
4969 The subset of the frame including the dtypes in ``include`` and
4970 excluding the dtypes in ``exclude``.
4971
4972 Raises
4973 ------
4974 ValueError
4975 * If both of ``include`` and ``exclude`` are empty
4976 * If ``include`` and ``exclude`` have overlapping elements
4977 * If any kind of string dtype is passed in.
4978
4979 See Also
4980 --------
4981 DataFrame.dtypes: Return Series with the data type of each column.
4982
4983 Notes
4984 -----
4985 * To select all *numeric* types, use ``np.number`` or ``'number'``
4986 * To select strings you must use the ``object`` dtype, but note that
4987 this will return *all* object dtype columns. With
4988 ``pd.options.future.infer_string`` enabled, using ``"str"`` will
4989 work to select all string columns.
4990 * See the `numpy dtype hierarchy
4991 <https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/arrays.scalars.html>`__
4992 * To select datetimes, use ``np.datetime64``, ``'datetime'`` or
4993 ``'datetime64'``
4994 * To select timedeltas, use ``np.timedelta64``, ``'timedelta'`` or
4995 ``'timedelta64'``
4996 * To select Pandas categorical dtypes, use ``'category'``
4997 * To select Pandas datetimetz dtypes, use ``'datetimetz'``
4998 or ``'datetime64[ns, tz]'``
4999
5000 Examples
5001 --------
5002 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1, 2] * 3,
5003 ... 'b': [True, False] * 3,
5004 ... 'c': [1.0, 2.0] * 3})
5005 >>> df
5006 a b c
5007 0 1 True 1.0
5008 1 2 False 2.0
5009 2 1 True 1.0
5010 3 2 False 2.0
5011 4 1 True 1.0
5012 5 2 False 2.0
5013
5014 >>> df.select_dtypes(include='bool')
5015 b
5016 0 True
5017 1 False
5018 2 True
5019 3 False
5020 4 True
5021 5 False
5022
5023 >>> df.select_dtypes(include=['float64'])
5024 c
5025 0 1.0
5026 1 2.0
5027 2 1.0
5028 3 2.0
5029 4 1.0
5030 5 2.0
5031
5032 >>> df.select_dtypes(exclude=['int64'])
5033 b c
5034 0 True 1.0
5035 1 False 2.0
5036 2 True 1.0
5037 3 False 2.0
5038 4 True 1.0
5039 5 False 2.0
5040 """
5041 if not is_list_like(include):
5042 include = (include,) if include is not None else ()
5043 if not is_list_like(exclude):
5044 exclude = (exclude,) if exclude is not None else ()
5045
5046 selection = (frozenset(include), frozenset(exclude))
5047
5048 if not any(selection):
5049 raise ValueError("at least one of include or exclude must be nonempty")
5050
5051 # convert the myriad valid dtypes object to a single representation
5052 def check_int_infer_dtype(dtypes):
5053 converted_dtypes: list[type] = []
5054 for dtype in dtypes:
5055 # Numpy maps int to different types (int32, in64) on Windows and Linux
5056 # see https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/9464
5057 if (isinstance(dtype, str) and dtype == "int") or (dtype is int):
5058 converted_dtypes.append(np.int32)
5059 converted_dtypes.append(np.int64)
5060 elif dtype == "float" or dtype is float:
5061 # GH#42452 : np.dtype("float") coerces to np.float64 from Numpy 1.20
5062 converted_dtypes.extend([np.float64, np.float32])
5063 else:
5064 converted_dtypes.append(infer_dtype_from_object(dtype))
5065 return frozenset(converted_dtypes)
5066
5067 include = check_int_infer_dtype(include)
5068 exclude = check_int_infer_dtype(exclude)
5069
5070 for dtypes in (include, exclude):
5071 invalidate_string_dtypes(dtypes)
5072
5073 # can't both include AND exclude!
5074 if not include.isdisjoint(exclude):
5075 raise ValueError(f"include and exclude overlap on {(include & exclude)}")
5076
5077 def dtype_predicate(dtype: DtypeObj, dtypes_set) -> bool:
5078 # GH 46870: BooleanDtype._is_numeric == True but should be excluded
5079 dtype = dtype if not isinstance(dtype, ArrowDtype) else dtype.numpy_dtype
5080 return issubclass(dtype.type, tuple(dtypes_set)) or (
5081 np.number in dtypes_set
5082 and getattr(dtype, "_is_numeric", False)
5083 and not is_bool_dtype(dtype)
5084 )
5085
5086 def predicate(arr: ArrayLike) -> bool:
5087 dtype = arr.dtype
5088 if include:
5089 if not dtype_predicate(dtype, include):
5090 return False
5091
5092 if exclude:
5093 if dtype_predicate(dtype, exclude):
5094 return False
5095
5096 return True
5097
5098 mgr = self._mgr._get_data_subset(predicate).copy(deep=None)
5099 # error: Incompatible return value type (got "DataFrame", expected "Self")
5100 return self._constructor_from_mgr(mgr, axes=mgr.axes).__finalize__(self) # type: ignore[return-value]
5101
5102 def insert(
5103 self,
5104 loc: int,
5105 column: Hashable,
5106 value: Scalar | AnyArrayLike,
5107 allow_duplicates: bool | lib.NoDefault = lib.no_default,
5108 ) -> None:
5109 """
5110 Insert column into DataFrame at specified location.
5111
5112 Raises a ValueError if `column` is already contained in the DataFrame,
5113 unless `allow_duplicates` is set to True.
5114
5115 Parameters
5116 ----------
5117 loc : int
5118 Insertion index. Must verify 0 <= loc <= len(columns).
5119 column : str, number, or hashable object
5120 Label of the inserted column.
5121 value : Scalar, Series, or array-like
5122 Content of the inserted column.
5123 allow_duplicates : bool, optional, default lib.no_default
5124 Allow duplicate column labels to be created.
5125
5126 See Also
5127 --------
5128 Index.insert : Insert new item by index.
5129
5130 Examples
5131 --------
5132 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]})
5133 >>> df
5134 col1 col2
5135 0 1 3
5136 1 2 4
5137 >>> df.insert(1, "newcol", [99, 99])
5138 >>> df
5139 col1 newcol col2
5140 0 1 99 3
5141 1 2 99 4
5142 >>> df.insert(0, "col1", [100, 100], allow_duplicates=True)
5143 >>> df
5144 col1 col1 newcol col2
5145 0 100 1 99 3
5146 1 100 2 99 4
5147
5148 Notice that pandas uses index alignment in case of `value` from type `Series`:
5149
5150 >>> df.insert(0, "col0", pd.Series([5, 6], index=[1, 2]))
5151 >>> df
5152 col0 col1 col1 newcol col2
5153 0 NaN 100 1 99 3
5154 1 5.0 100 2 99 4
5155 """
5156 if allow_duplicates is lib.no_default:
5157 allow_duplicates = False
5158 if allow_duplicates and not self.flags.allows_duplicate_labels:
5159 raise ValueError(
5160 "Cannot specify 'allow_duplicates=True' when "
5161 "'self.flags.allows_duplicate_labels' is False."
5162 )
5163 if not allow_duplicates and column in self.columns:
5164 # Should this be a different kind of error??
5165 raise ValueError(f"cannot insert {column}, already exists")
5166 if not is_integer(loc):
5167 raise TypeError("loc must be int")
5168 # convert non stdlib ints to satisfy typing checks
5169 loc = int(loc)
5170 if isinstance(value, DataFrame) and len(value.columns) > 1:
5171 raise ValueError(
5172 f"Expected a one-dimensional object, got a DataFrame with "
5173 f"{len(value.columns)} columns instead."
5174 )
5175 elif isinstance(value, DataFrame):
5176 value = value.iloc[:, 0]
5177
5178 value, refs = self._sanitize_column(value)
5179 self._mgr.insert(loc, column, value, refs=refs)
5180
5181 def assign(self, **kwargs) -> DataFrame:
5182 r"""
5183 Assign new columns to a DataFrame.
5184
5185 Returns a new object with all original columns in addition to new ones.
5186 Existing columns that are re-assigned will be overwritten.
5187
5188 Parameters
5189 ----------
5190 **kwargs : dict of {str: callable or Series}
5191 The column names are keywords. If the values are
5192 callable, they are computed on the DataFrame and
5193 assigned to the new columns. The callable must not
5194 change input DataFrame (though pandas doesn't check it).
5195 If the values are not callable, (e.g. a Series, scalar, or array),
5196 they are simply assigned.
5197
5198 Returns
5199 -------
5200 DataFrame
5201 A new DataFrame with the new columns in addition to
5202 all the existing columns.
5203
5204 Notes
5205 -----
5206 Assigning multiple columns within the same ``assign`` is possible.
5207 Later items in '\*\*kwargs' may refer to newly created or modified
5208 columns in 'df'; items are computed and assigned into 'df' in order.
5209
5210 Examples
5211 --------
5212 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'temp_c': [17.0, 25.0]},
5213 ... index=['Portland', 'Berkeley'])
5214 >>> df
5215 temp_c
5216 Portland 17.0
5217 Berkeley 25.0
5218
5219 Where the value is a callable, evaluated on `df`:
5220
5221 >>> df.assign(temp_f=lambda x: x.temp_c * 9 / 5 + 32)
5222 temp_c temp_f
5223 Portland 17.0 62.6
5224 Berkeley 25.0 77.0
5225
5226 Alternatively, the same behavior can be achieved by directly
5227 referencing an existing Series or sequence:
5228
5229 >>> df.assign(temp_f=df['temp_c'] * 9 / 5 + 32)
5230 temp_c temp_f
5231 Portland 17.0 62.6
