5232 Berkeley 25.0 77.0
5233
5234 You can create multiple columns within the same assign where one
5235 of the columns depends on another one defined within the same assign:
5236
5237 >>> df.assign(temp_f=lambda x: x['temp_c'] * 9 / 5 + 32,
5238 ... temp_k=lambda x: (x['temp_f'] + 459.67) * 5 / 9)
5239 temp_c temp_f temp_k
5240 Portland 17.0 62.6 290.15
5241 Berkeley 25.0 77.0 298.15
5242 """
5243 data = self.copy(deep=None)
5244
5245 for k, v in kwargs.items():
5246 data[k] = com.apply_if_callable(v, data)
5247 return data
5248
5249 def _sanitize_column(self, value) -> tuple[ArrayLike, BlockValuesRefs | None]:
5250 """
5251 Ensures new columns (which go into the BlockManager as new blocks) are
5252 always copied (or a reference is being tracked to them under CoW)
5253 and converted into an array.
5254
5255 Parameters
5256 ----------
5257 value : scalar, Series, or array-like
5258
5259 Returns
5260 -------
5261 tuple of numpy.ndarray or ExtensionArray and optional BlockValuesRefs
5262 """
5263 self._ensure_valid_index(value)
5264
5265 # Using a DataFrame would mean coercing values to one dtype
5266 assert not isinstance(value, DataFrame)
5267 if is_dict_like(value):
5268 if not isinstance(value, Series):
5269 value = Series(value)
5270 return _reindex_for_setitem(value, self.index)
5271
5272 if is_list_like(value):
5273 com.require_length_match(value, self.index)
5274 arr = sanitize_array(value, self.index, copy=True, allow_2d=True)
5275 if (
5276 isinstance(value, Index)
5277 and value.dtype == "object"
5278 and arr.dtype != value.dtype
5279 ): #
5280 # TODO: Remove kludge in sanitize_array for string mode when enforcing
5281 # this deprecation
5282 warnings.warn(
5283 "Setting an Index with object dtype into a DataFrame will stop "
5284 "inferring another dtype in a future version. Cast the Index "
5285 "explicitly before setting it into the DataFrame.",
5286 FutureWarning,
5287 stacklevel=find_stack_level(),
5288 )
5289 return arr, None
5290
5291 @property
5292 def _series(self):
5293 return {item: self._ixs(idx, axis=1) for idx, item in enumerate(self.columns)}
5294
5295 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
5296 # Reindexing and alignment
5297
5298 def _reindex_multi(
5299 self, axes: dict[str, Index], copy: bool, fill_value
5300 ) -> DataFrame:
5301 """
5302 We are guaranteed non-Nones in the axes.
5303 """
5304
5305 new_index, row_indexer = self.index.reindex(axes["index"])
5306 new_columns, col_indexer = self.columns.reindex(axes["columns"])
5307
5308 if row_indexer is not None and col_indexer is not None:
5309 # Fastpath. By doing two 'take's at once we avoid making an
5310 # unnecessary copy.
5311 # We only get here with `self._can_fast_transpose`, which (almost)
5312 # ensures that self.values is cheap. It may be worth making this
5313 # condition more specific.
5314 indexer = row_indexer, col_indexer
5315 new_values = take_2d_multi(self.values, indexer, fill_value=fill_value)
5316 return self._constructor(
5317 new_values, index=new_index, columns=new_columns, copy=False
5318 )
5319 else:
5320 return self._reindex_with_indexers(
5321 {0: [new_index, row_indexer], 1: [new_columns, col_indexer]},
5322 copy=copy,
5323 fill_value=fill_value,
5324 )
5325
5326 @Appender(
5327 """
5328 Examples
5329 --------
5330 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"A": [1, 2, 3], "B": [4, 5, 6]})
5331
5332 Change the row labels.
5333
5334 >>> df.set_axis(['a', 'b', 'c'], axis='index')
5335 A B
5336 a 1 4
5337 b 2 5
5338 c 3 6
5339
5340 Change the column labels.
5341
5342 >>> df.set_axis(['I', 'II'], axis='columns')
5343 I II
5344 0 1 4
5345 1 2 5
5346 2 3 6
5347 """
5348 )
5349 @Substitution(
5350 klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"],
5351 axes_single_arg=_shared_doc_kwargs["axes_single_arg"],
5352 extended_summary_sub=" column or",
5353 axis_description_sub=", and 1 identifies the columns",
5354 see_also_sub=" or columns",
5355 )
5356 @Appender(NDFrame.set_axis.__doc__)
5357 def set_axis(
5358 self,
5359 labels,
5360 *,
5361 axis: Axis = 0,
5362 copy: bool | None = None,
5363 ) -> DataFrame:
5364 return super().set_axis(labels, axis=axis, copy=copy)
5365
5366 @doc(
5367 NDFrame.reindex,
5368 klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"],
5369 optional_reindex=_shared_doc_kwargs["optional_reindex"],
5370 )
5371 def reindex(
5372 self,
5373 labels=None,
5374 *,
5375 index=None,
5376 columns=None,
5377 axis: Axis | None = None,
5378 method: ReindexMethod | None = None,
5379 copy: bool | None = None,
5380 level: Level | None = None,
5381 fill_value: Scalar | None = np.nan,
5382 limit: int | None = None,
5383 tolerance=None,
5384 ) -> DataFrame:
5385 return super().reindex(
5386 labels=labels,
5387 index=index,
5388 columns=columns,
5389 axis=axis,
5390 method=method,
5391 copy=copy,
5392 level=level,
5393 fill_value=fill_value,
5394 limit=limit,
5395 tolerance=tolerance,
5396 )
5397
5398 @overload
5399 def drop(
5400 self,
5401 labels: IndexLabel = ...,
5402 *,
5403 axis: Axis = ...,
5404 index: IndexLabel = ...,
5405 columns: IndexLabel = ...,
5406 level: Level = ...,
5407 inplace: Literal[True],
5408 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5409 ) -> None:
5410 ...
5411
5412 @overload
5413 def drop(
5414 self,
5415 labels: IndexLabel = ...,
5416 *,
5417 axis: Axis = ...,
5418 index: IndexLabel = ...,
5419 columns: IndexLabel = ...,
5420 level: Level = ...,
5421 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
5422 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5423 ) -> DataFrame:
5424 ...
5425
5426 @overload
5427 def drop(
5428 self,
5429 labels: IndexLabel = ...,
5430 *,
5431 axis: Axis = ...,
5432 index: IndexLabel = ...,
5433 columns: IndexLabel = ...,
5434 level: Level = ...,
5435 inplace: bool = ...,
5436 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5437 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5438 ...
5439
5440 def drop(
5441 self,
5442 labels: IndexLabel | None = None,
5443 *,
5444 axis: Axis = 0,
5445 index: IndexLabel | None = None,
5446 columns: IndexLabel | None = None,
5447 level: Level | None = None,
5448 inplace: bool = False,
5449 errors: IgnoreRaise = "raise",
5450 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5451 """
5452 Drop specified labels from rows or columns.
5453
5454 Remove rows or columns by specifying label names and corresponding
5455 axis, or by directly specifying index or column names. When using a
5456 multi-index, labels on different levels can be removed by specifying
5457 the level. See the :ref:`user guide <advanced.shown_levels>`
5458 for more information about the now unused levels.
5459
5460 Parameters
5461 ----------
5462 labels : single label or list-like
5463 Index or column labels to drop. A tuple will be used as a single
5464 label and not treated as a list-like.
5465 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
5466 Whether to drop labels from the index (0 or 'index') or
5467 columns (1 or 'columns').
5468 index : single label or list-like
5469 Alternative to specifying axis (``labels, axis=0``
5470 is equivalent to ``index=labels``).
5471 columns : single label or list-like
5472 Alternative to specifying axis (``labels, axis=1``
5473 is equivalent to ``columns=labels``).
5474 level : int or level name, optional
5475 For MultiIndex, level from which the labels will be removed.
5476 inplace : bool, default False
5477 If False, return a copy. Otherwise, do operation
5478 in place and return None.
5479 errors : {'ignore', 'raise'}, default 'raise'
5480 If 'ignore', suppress error and only existing labels are
5481 dropped.
5482
5483 Returns
5484 -------
5485 DataFrame or None
5486 Returns DataFrame or None DataFrame with the specified
5487 index or column labels removed or None if inplace=True.
5488
5489 Raises
5490 ------
5491 KeyError
5492 If any of the labels is not found in the selected axis.
5493
5494 See Also
5495 --------
5496 DataFrame.loc : Label-location based indexer for selection by label.
5497 DataFrame.dropna : Return DataFrame with labels on given axis omitted
5498 where (all or any) data are missing.
5499 DataFrame.drop_duplicates : Return DataFrame with duplicate rows
5500 removed, optionally only considering certain columns.
5501 Series.drop : Return Series with specified index labels removed.
5502
5503 Examples
5504 --------
5505 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.arange(12).reshape(3, 4),
5506 ... columns=['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'])
5507 >>> df
5508 A B C D
5509 0 0 1 2 3
5510 1 4 5 6 7
5511 2 8 9 10 11
5512
5513 Drop columns
5514
5515 >>> df.drop(['B', 'C'], axis=1)
5516 A D
5517 0 0 3
5518 1 4 7
5519 2 8 11
5520
5521 >>> df.drop(columns=['B', 'C'])
5522 A D
5523 0 0 3
5524 1 4 7
5525 2 8 11
5526
5527 Drop a row by index
5528
5529 >>> df.drop([0, 1])
5530 A B C D
5531 2 8 9 10 11
5532
5533 Drop columns and/or rows of MultiIndex DataFrame
5534
5535 >>> midx = pd.MultiIndex(levels=[['llama', 'cow', 'falcon'],
5536 ... ['speed', 'weight', 'length']],
5537 ... codes=[[0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2],
5538 ... [0, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2]])
5539 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(index=midx, columns=['big', 'small'],
5540 ... data=[[45, 30], [200, 100], [1.5, 1], [30, 20],
5541 ... [250, 150], [1.5, 0.8], [320, 250],
5542 ... [1, 0.8], [0.3, 0.2]])
5543 >>> df
5544 big small
5545 llama speed 45.0 30.0
5546 weight 200.0 100.0
5547 length 1.5 1.0
5548 cow speed 30.0 20.0
5549 weight 250.0 150.0
5550 length 1.5 0.8
5551 falcon speed 320.0 250.0
5552 weight 1.0 0.8
5553 length 0.3 0.2
5554
5555 Drop a specific index combination from the MultiIndex
5556 DataFrame, i.e., drop the combination ``'falcon'`` and
5557 ``'weight'``, which deletes only the corresponding row
5558
5559 >>> df.drop(index=('falcon', 'weight'))
5560 big small
5561 llama speed 45.0 30.0
5562 weight 200.0 100.0
5563 length 1.5 1.0
5564 cow speed 30.0 20.0
5565 weight 250.0 150.0
5566 length 1.5 0.8
5567 falcon speed 320.0 250.0
5568 length 0.3 0.2
5569
5570 >>> df.drop(index='cow', columns='small')
5571 big
5572 llama speed 45.0
5573 weight 200.0
5574 length 1.5
5575 falcon speed 320.0
5576 weight 1.0
5577 length 0.3
5578
5579 >>> df.drop(index='length', level=1)
5580 big small
5581 llama speed 45.0 30.0
5582 weight 200.0 100.0
5583 cow speed 30.0 20.0
5584 weight 250.0 150.0
5585 falcon speed 320.0 250.0
5586 weight 1.0 0.8
5587 """
5588 return super().drop(
5589 labels=labels,
5590 axis=axis,
5591 index=index,
5592 columns=columns,
5593 level=level,
5594 inplace=inplace,
5595 errors=errors,
5596 )
5597
5598 @overload
5599 def rename(
5600 self,
5601 mapper: Renamer | None = ...,
5602 *,
5603 index: Renamer | None = ...,
5604 columns: Renamer | None = ...,
5605 axis: Axis | None = ...,
5606 copy: bool | None = ...,
5607 inplace: Literal[True],
5608 level: Level = ...,
5609 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5610 ) -> None:
5611 ...
5612
5613 @overload
5614 def rename(
5615 self,
5616 mapper: Renamer | None = ...,
5617 *,
5618 index: Renamer | None = ...,
5619 columns: Renamer | None = ...,
5620 axis: Axis | None = ...,
5621 copy: bool | None = ...,
5622 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
5623 level: Level = ...,
5624 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5625 ) -> DataFrame:
5626 ...
5627
5628 @overload
5629 def rename(
5630 self,
5631 mapper: Renamer | None = ...,
5632 *,
5633 index: Renamer | None = ...,
5634 columns: Renamer | None = ...,
5635 axis: Axis | None = ...,
5636 copy: bool | None = ...,
5637 inplace: bool = ...,
5638 level: Level = ...,
5639 errors: IgnoreRaise = ...,
5640 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5641 ...
5642
5643 def rename(
5644 self,
5645 mapper: Renamer | None = None,
5646 *,
5647 index: Renamer | None = None,
5648 columns: Renamer | None = None,
5649 axis: Axis | None = None,
5650 copy: bool | None = None,
5651 inplace: bool = False,
5652 level: Level | None = None,
5653 errors: IgnoreRaise = "ignore",
5654 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5655 """
5656 Rename columns or index labels.
5657
5658 Function / dict values must be unique (1-to-1). Labels not contained in
5659 a dict / Series will be left as-is. Extra labels listed don't throw an
5660 error.
5661
5662 See the :ref:`user guide <basics.rename>` for more.
5663
5664 Parameters
5665 ----------
5666 mapper : dict-like or function
5667 Dict-like or function transformations to apply to
5668 that axis' values. Use either ``mapper`` and ``axis`` to
5669 specify the axis to target with ``mapper``, or ``index`` and
5670 ``columns``.
5671 index : dict-like or function
5672 Alternative to specifying axis (``mapper, axis=0``
5673 is equivalent to ``index=mapper``).
5674 columns : dict-like or function
5675 Alternative to specifying axis (``mapper, axis=1``
5676 is equivalent to ``columns=mapper``).
5677 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
5678 Axis to target with ``mapper``. Can be either the axis name
5679 ('index', 'columns') or number (0, 1). The default is 'index'.
5680 copy : bool, default True
5681 Also copy underlying data.
5682
5683 .. note::
5684 The `copy` keyword will change behavior in pandas 3.0.
5685 `Copy-on-Write
5686 <https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/user_guide/copy_on_write.html>`__
5687 will be enabled by default, which means that all methods with a
5688 `copy` keyword will use a lazy copy mechanism to defer the copy and
5689 ignore the `copy` keyword. The `copy` keyword will be removed in a
5690 future version of pandas.
5691
5692 You can already get the future behavior and improvements through
5693 enabling copy on write ``pd.options.mode.copy_on_write = True``
5694 inplace : bool, default False
5695 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
5696 If True then value of copy is ignored.
5697 level : int or level name, default None
5698 In case of a MultiIndex, only rename labels in the specified
5699 level.
5700 errors : {'ignore', 'raise'}, default 'ignore'
5701 If 'raise', raise a `KeyError` when a dict-like `mapper`, `index`,
5702 or `columns` contains labels that are not present in the Index
5703 being transformed.
5704 If 'ignore', existing keys will be renamed and extra keys will be
5705 ignored.
5706
5707 Returns
5708 -------
5709 DataFrame or None
5710 DataFrame with the renamed axis labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
5711
5712 Raises
5713 ------
5714 KeyError
5715 If any of the labels is not found in the selected axis and
5716 "errors='raise'".
5717
5718 See Also
5719 --------
5720 DataFrame.rename_axis : Set the name of the axis.
5721
5722 Examples
5723 --------
5724 ``DataFrame.rename`` supports two calling conventions
5725
5726 * ``(index=index_mapper, columns=columns_mapper, ...)``
5727 * ``(mapper, axis={'index', 'columns'}, ...)``
5728
5729 We *highly* recommend using keyword arguments to clarify your
5730 intent.
5731
5732 Rename columns using a mapping:
5733
5734 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"A": [1, 2, 3], "B": [4, 5, 6]})
5735 >>> df.rename(columns={"A": "a", "B": "c"})
5736 a c
5737 0 1 4
5738 1 2 5
5739 2 3 6
5740
5741 Rename index using a mapping:
5742
5743 >>> df.rename(index={0: "x", 1: "y", 2: "z"})
5744 A B
5745 x 1 4
5746 y 2 5
5747 z 3 6
5748
5749 Cast index labels to a different type:
5750
5751 >>> df.index
5752 RangeIndex(start=0, stop=3, step=1)
5753 >>> df.rename(index=str).index
5754 Index(['0', '1', '2'], dtype='object')
5755
5756 >>> df.rename(columns={"A": "a", "B": "b", "C": "c"}, errors="raise")
5757 Traceback (most recent call last):
5758 KeyError: ['C'] not found in axis
5759
5760 Using axis-style parameters:
5761
5762 >>> df.rename(str.lower, axis='columns')
5763 a b
5764 0 1 4
5765 1 2 5
5766 2 3 6
5767
5768 >>> df.rename({1: 2, 2: 4}, axis='index')
5769 A B
5770 0 1 4
5771 2 2 5
5772 4 3 6
5773 """
5774 return super()._rename(
5775 mapper=mapper,
5776 index=index,
5777 columns=columns,
5778 axis=axis,
5779 copy=copy,
5780 inplace=inplace,
5781 level=level,
5782 errors=errors,
5783 )
5784
5785 def pop(self, item: Hashable) -> Series:
5786 """
5787 Return item and drop from frame. Raise KeyError if not found.
5788
5789 Parameters
5790 ----------
5791 item : label
5792 Label of column to be popped.
5793
5794 Returns
5795 -------
5796 Series
5797
5798 Examples
5799 --------
5800 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([('falcon', 'bird', 389.0),
5801 ... ('parrot', 'bird', 24.0),
5802 ... ('lion', 'mammal', 80.5),
5803 ... ('monkey', 'mammal', np.nan)],
5804 ... columns=('name', 'class', 'max_speed'))
5805 >>> df
5806 name class max_speed
5807 0 falcon bird 389.0
5808 1 parrot bird 24.0
5809 2 lion mammal 80.5
5810 3 monkey mammal NaN
5811
5812 >>> df.pop('class')
5813 0 bird
5814 1 bird
5815 2 mammal
5816 3 mammal
5817 Name: class, dtype: object
5818
5819 >>> df
5820 name max_speed
5821 0 falcon 389.0
5822 1 parrot 24.0
5823 2 lion 80.5
5824 3 monkey NaN
5825 """
5826 return super().pop(item=item)
5827
5828 def _replace_columnwise(
5829 self, mapping: dict[Hashable, tuple[Any, Any]], inplace: bool, regex
5830 ):
5831 """
5832 Dispatch to Series.replace column-wise.
5833
5834 Parameters
5835 ----------
5836 mapping : dict
5837 of the form {col: (target, value)}
5838 inplace : bool
5839 regex : bool or same types as `to_replace` in DataFrame.replace
5840
5841 Returns
5842 -------
5843 DataFrame or None
5844 """
5845 # Operate column-wise
5846 res = self if inplace else self.copy(deep=None)
5847 ax = self.columns
5848
5849 for i, ax_value in enumerate(ax):
5850 if ax_value in mapping:
5851 ser = self.iloc[:, i]
5852
5853 target, value = mapping[ax_value]
5854 newobj = ser.replace(target, value, regex=regex)
5855
5856 res._iset_item(i, newobj, inplace=inplace)
5857
5858 if inplace:
5859 return
5860 return res.__finalize__(self)
5861
5862 @doc(NDFrame.shift, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
5863 def shift(
5864 self,
5865 periods: int | Sequence[int] = 1,
5866 freq: Frequency | None = None,
5867 axis: Axis = 0,
5868 fill_value: Hashable = lib.no_default,
5869 suffix: str | None = None,
5870 ) -> DataFrame:
5871 if freq is not None and fill_value is not lib.no_default:
5872 # GH#53832
5873 warnings.warn(
5874 "Passing a 'freq' together with a 'fill_value' silently ignores "
5875 "the fill_value and is deprecated. This will raise in a future "
5876 "version.",
5877 FutureWarning,
5878 stacklevel=find_stack_level(),
5879 )
5880 fill_value = lib.no_default
5881
5882 if self.empty:
5883 return self.copy()
5884
5885 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
5886
5887 if is_list_like(periods):
5888 periods = cast(Sequence, periods)
5889 if axis == 1:
5890 raise ValueError(
5891 "If `periods` contains multiple shifts, `axis` cannot be 1."
5892 )
5893 if len(periods) == 0:
5894 raise ValueError("If `periods` is an iterable, it cannot be empty.")
5895 from pandas.core.reshape.concat import concat
5896
5897 shifted_dataframes = []
5898 for period in periods:
5899 if not is_integer(period):
5900 raise TypeError(
5901 f"Periods must be integer, but {period} is {type(period)}."
5902 )
5903 period = cast(int, period)
5904 shifted_dataframes.append(
5905 super()
5906 .shift(periods=period, freq=freq, axis=axis, fill_value=fill_value)
5907 .add_suffix(f"{suffix}_{period}" if suffix else f"_{period}")
5908 )
5909 return concat(shifted_dataframes, axis=1)
5910 elif suffix:
5911 raise ValueError("Cannot specify `suffix` if `periods` is an int.")
5912 periods = cast(int, periods)
5913
5914 ncols = len(self.columns)
5915 arrays = self._mgr.arrays
5916 if axis == 1 and periods != 0 and ncols > 0 and freq is None:
5917 if fill_value is lib.no_default:
5918 # We will infer fill_value to match the closest column
5919
5920 # Use a column that we know is valid for our column's dtype GH#38434
5921 label = self.columns[0]
5922
5923 if periods > 0:
5924 result = self.iloc[:, :-periods]
5925 for col in range(min(ncols, abs(periods))):
5926 # TODO(EA2D): doing this in a loop unnecessary with 2D EAs
5927 # Define filler inside loop so we get a copy
5928 filler = self.iloc[:, 0].shift(len(self))
5929 result.insert(0, label, filler, allow_duplicates=True)
5930 else:
5931 result = self.iloc[:, -periods:]
5932 for col in range(min(ncols, abs(periods))):
5933 # Define filler inside loop so we get a copy
5934 filler = self.iloc[:, -1].shift(len(self))
5935 result.insert(
5936 len(result.columns), label, filler, allow_duplicates=True
5937 )
5938
5939 result.columns = self.columns.copy()
5940 return result
5941 elif len(arrays) > 1 or (
5942 # If we only have one block and we know that we can't
5943 # keep the same dtype (i.e. the _can_hold_element check)
5944 # then we can go through the reindex_indexer path
5945 # (and avoid casting logic in the Block method).
5946 not can_hold_element(arrays[0], fill_value)
5947 ):
5948 # GH#35488 we need to watch out for multi-block cases
5949 # We only get here with fill_value not-lib.no_default
5950 nper = abs(periods)
5951 nper = min(nper, ncols)
5952 if periods > 0:
5953 indexer = np.array(
5954 [-1] * nper + list(range(ncols - periods)), dtype=np.intp
5955 )
5956 else:
5957 indexer = np.array(
5958 list(range(nper, ncols)) + [-1] * nper, dtype=np.intp
5959 )
5960 mgr = self._mgr.reindex_indexer(
5961 self.columns,
5962 indexer,
5963 axis=0,
5964 fill_value=fill_value,
5965 allow_dups=True,
5966 )
5967 res_df = self._constructor_from_mgr(mgr, axes=mgr.axes)
5968 return res_df.__finalize__(self, method="shift")
5969 else:
5970 return self.T.shift(periods=periods, fill_value=fill_value).T
5971
5972 return super().shift(
5973 periods=periods, freq=freq, axis=axis, fill_value=fill_value
5974 )
5975
5976 @overload
5977 def set_index(
5978 self,
5979 keys,
5980 *,
5981 drop: bool = ...,
5982 append: bool = ...,
5983 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
5984 verify_integrity: bool = ...,
5985 ) -> DataFrame:
5986 ...
5987
5988 @overload
5989 def set_index(
5990 self,
5991 keys,
5992 *,
5993 drop: bool = ...,
5994 append: bool = ...,
5995 inplace: Literal[True],
5996 verify_integrity: bool = ...,
5997 ) -> None:
5998 ...
5999
6000 def set_index(
6001 self,
6002 keys,
6003 *,
6004 drop: bool = True,
6005 append: bool = False,
6006 inplace: bool = False,
6007 verify_integrity: bool = False,
6008 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6009 """
6010 Set the DataFrame index using existing columns.
6011
6012 Set the DataFrame index (row labels) using one or more existing
6013 columns or arrays (of the correct length). The index can replace the
6014 existing index or expand on it.
6015
6016 Parameters
6017 ----------
6018 keys : label or array-like or list of labels/arrays
6019 This parameter can be either a single column key, a single array of
6020 the same length as the calling DataFrame, or a list containing an
6021 arbitrary combination of column keys and arrays. Here, "array"
6022 encompasses :class:`Series`, :class:`Index`, ``np.ndarray``, and
6023 instances of :class:`~collections.abc.Iterator`.
6024 drop : bool, default True
6025 Delete columns to be used as the new index.
6026 append : bool, default False
6027 Whether to append columns to existing index.
6028 inplace : bool, default False
6029 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
6030 verify_integrity : bool, default False
6031 Check the new index for duplicates. Otherwise defer the check until
6032 necessary. Setting to False will improve the performance of this
6033 method.
6034
6035 Returns
6036 -------
6037 DataFrame or None
6038 Changed row labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
6039
6040 See Also
6041 --------
6042 DataFrame.reset_index : Opposite of set_index.
6043 DataFrame.reindex : Change to new indices or expand indices.
6044 DataFrame.reindex_like : Change to same indices as other DataFrame.
6045
6046 Examples
6047 --------
6048 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'month': [1, 4, 7, 10],
6049 ... 'year': [2012, 2014, 2013, 2014],
6050 ... 'sale': [55, 40, 84, 31]})
6051 >>> df
6052 month year sale
6053 0 1 2012 55
6054 1 4 2014 40
6055 2 7 2013 84
6056 3 10 2014 31
6057
6058 Set the index to become the 'month' column:
6059
6060 >>> df.set_index('month')
6061 year sale
6062 month
6063 1 2012 55
6064 4 2014 40
6065 7 2013 84
6066 10 2014 31
6067
6068 Create a MultiIndex using columns 'year' and 'month':
6069
6070 >>> df.set_index(['year', 'month'])
6071 sale
6072 year month
6073 2012 1 55
6074 2014 4 40
6075 2013 7 84
6076 2014 10 31
6077
6078 Create a MultiIndex using an Index and a column:
6079
6080 >>> df.set_index([pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]), 'year'])
6081 month sale
6082 year
6083 1 2012 1 55
6084 2 2014 4 40
6085 3 2013 7 84
6086 4 2014 10 31
6087
6088 Create a MultiIndex using two Series:
6089
6090 >>> s = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4])
6091 >>> df.set_index([s, s**2])
6092 month year sale
6093 1 1 1 2012 55
6094 2 4 4 2014 40
6095 3 9 7 2013 84
6096 4 16 10 2014 31
6097 """
6098 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
6099 self._check_inplace_and_allows_duplicate_labels(inplace)
6100 if not isinstance(keys, list):
6101 keys = [keys]
6102
6103 err_msg = (
6104 'The parameter "keys" may be a column key, one-dimensional '
6105 "array, or a list containing only valid column keys and "
6106 "one-dimensional arrays."
6107 )
6108
6109 missing: list[Hashable] = []
6110 for col in keys:
6111 if isinstance(col, (Index, Series, np.ndarray, list, abc.Iterator)):
6112 # arrays are fine as long as they are one-dimensional
6113 # iterators get converted to list below
6114 if getattr(col, "ndim", 1) != 1:
6115 raise ValueError(err_msg)
6116 else:
6117 # everything else gets tried as a key; see GH 24969
6118 try:
6119 found = col in self.columns
6120 except TypeError as err:
6121 raise TypeError(
6122 f"{err_msg}. Received column of type {type(col)}"
6123 ) from err
6124 else:
6125 if not found:
6126 missing.append(col)
6127
6128 if missing:
6129 raise KeyError(f"None of {missing} are in the columns")
6130
6131 if inplace:
6132 frame = self
6133 else:
6134 # GH 49473 Use "lazy copy" with Copy-on-Write
6135 frame = self.copy(deep=None)
6136
6137 arrays: list[Index] = []
6138 names: list[Hashable] = []
6139 if append:
6140 names = list(self.index.names)
6141 if isinstance(self.index, MultiIndex):
6142 arrays.extend(
6143 self.index._get_level_values(i) for i in range(self.index.nlevels)
6144 )
6145 else:
6146 arrays.append(self.index)
6147
6148 to_remove: list[Hashable] = []
6149 for col in keys:
6150 if isinstance(col, MultiIndex):
6151 arrays.extend(col._get_level_values(n) for n in range(col.nlevels))
6152 names.extend(col.names)
6153 elif isinstance(col, (Index, Series)):
6154 # if Index then not MultiIndex (treated above)
6155
6156 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
6157 # "Union[Index, Series]"; expected "Index"
6158 arrays.append(col) # type: ignore[arg-type]
6159 names.append(col.name)
6160 elif isinstance(col, (list, np.ndarray)):
6161 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
6162 # "Union[List[Any], ndarray]"; expected "Index"
6163 arrays.append(col) # type: ignore[arg-type]
6164 names.append(None)
6165 elif isinstance(col, abc.Iterator):
6166 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
6167 # "List[Any]"; expected "Index"
6168 arrays.append(list(col)) # type: ignore[arg-type]
6169 names.append(None)
6170 # from here, col can only be a column label
6171 else:
6172 arrays.append(frame[col])
6173 names.append(col)
6174 if drop:
6175 to_remove.append(col)
6176
6177 if len(arrays[-1]) != len(self):
6178 # check newest element against length of calling frame, since
6179 # ensure_index_from_sequences would not raise for append=False.
6180 raise ValueError(
6181 f"Length mismatch: Expected {len(self)} rows, "
6182 f"received array of length {len(arrays[-1])}"
6183 )
6184
6185 index = ensure_index_from_sequences(arrays, names)
6186
6187 if verify_integrity and not index.is_unique:
6188 duplicates = index[index.duplicated()].unique()
6189 raise ValueError(f"Index has duplicate keys: {duplicates}")
6190
6191 # use set to handle duplicate column names gracefully in case of drop
6192 for c in set(to_remove):
6193 del frame[c]
6194
6195 # clear up memory usage
6196 index._cleanup()
6197
6198 frame.index = index
6199
6200 if not inplace:
6201 return frame
6202 return None
6203
6204 @overload
6205 def reset_index(
6206 self,
6207 level: IndexLabel = ...,
6208 *,
6209 drop: bool = ...,
6210 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
6211 col_level: Hashable = ...,
6212 col_fill: Hashable = ...,
6213 allow_duplicates: bool | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6214 names: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6215 ) -> DataFrame:
6216 ...
6217
6218 @overload
6219 def reset_index(
6220 self,
6221 level: IndexLabel = ...,
6222 *,
6223 drop: bool = ...,
6224 inplace: Literal[True],
6225 col_level: Hashable = ...,
6226 col_fill: Hashable = ...,
6227 allow_duplicates: bool | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6228 names: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6229 ) -> None:
6230 ...
6231
6232 @overload
6233 def reset_index(
6234 self,
6235 level: IndexLabel = ...,
6236 *,
6237 drop: bool = ...,
6238 inplace: bool = ...,
6239 col_level: Hashable = ...,
6240 col_fill: Hashable = ...,
6241 allow_duplicates: bool | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6242 names: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6243 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6244 ...
6245
6246 def reset_index(
6247 self,
6248 level: IndexLabel | None = None,
6249 *,
6250 drop: bool = False,
6251 inplace: bool = False,
6252 col_level: Hashable = 0,
6253 col_fill: Hashable = "",
6254 allow_duplicates: bool | lib.NoDefault = lib.no_default,
6255 names: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6256 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6257 """
6258 Reset the index, or a level of it.
6259
6260 Reset the index of the DataFrame, and use the default one instead.
6261 If the DataFrame has a MultiIndex, this method can remove one or more
6262 levels.
6263
6264 Parameters
6265 ----------
6266 level : int, str, tuple, or list, default None
6267 Only remove the given levels from the index. Removes all levels by
6268 default.
6269 drop : bool, default False
6270 Do not try to insert index into dataframe columns. This resets
6271 the index to the default integer index.
6272 inplace : bool, default False
6273 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
6274 col_level : int or str, default 0
6275 If the columns have multiple levels, determines which level the
6276 labels are inserted into. By default it is inserted into the first
6277 level.
6278 col_fill : object, default ''
6279 If the columns have multiple levels, determines how the other
6280 levels are named. If None then the index name is repeated.
6281 allow_duplicates : bool, optional, default lib.no_default
6282 Allow duplicate column labels to be created.
6283
6284 .. versionadded:: 1.5.0
6285
6286 names : int, str or 1-dimensional list, default None
6287 Using the given string, rename the DataFrame column which contains the
6288 index data. If the DataFrame has a MultiIndex, this has to be a list or
6289 tuple with length equal to the number of levels.
6290
6291 .. versionadded:: 1.5.0
6292
6293 Returns
6294 -------
6295 DataFrame or None
6296 DataFrame with the new index or None if ``inplace=True``.
6297
6298 See Also
6299 --------
6300 DataFrame.set_index : Opposite of reset_index.
6301 DataFrame.reindex : Change to new indices or expand indices.
6302 DataFrame.reindex_like : Change to same indices as other DataFrame.
6303
6304 Examples
6305 --------
6306 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([('bird', 389.0),
6307 ... ('bird', 24.0),
6308 ... ('mammal', 80.5),
6309 ... ('mammal', np.nan)],
6310 ... index=['falcon', 'parrot', 'lion', 'monkey'],
6311 ... columns=('class', 'max_speed'))
6312 >>> df
6313 class max_speed
6314 falcon bird 389.0
6315 parrot bird 24.0
6316 lion mammal 80.5
6317 monkey mammal NaN
6318
6319 When we reset the index, the old index is added as a column, and a
6320 new sequential index is used:
6321
6322 >>> df.reset_index()
6323 index class max_speed
6324 0 falcon bird 389.0
6325 1 parrot bird 24.0
6326 2 lion mammal 80.5
6327 3 monkey mammal NaN
6328
6329 We can use the `drop` parameter to avoid the old index being added as
6330 a column:
6331
6332 >>> df.reset_index(drop=True)
6333 class max_speed
6334 0 bird 389.0
6335 1 bird 24.0
6336 2 mammal 80.5
6337 3 mammal NaN
6338
6339 You can also use `reset_index` with `MultiIndex`.
6340
6341 >>> index = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('bird', 'falcon'),
6342 ... ('bird', 'parrot'),
6343 ... ('mammal', 'lion'),
6344 ... ('mammal', 'monkey')],
6345 ... names=['class', 'name'])
6346 >>> columns = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('speed', 'max'),
6347 ... ('species', 'type')])
6348 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([(389.0, 'fly'),
6349 ... (24.0, 'fly'),
6350 ... (80.5, 'run'),
6351 ... (np.nan, 'jump')],
6352 ... index=index,
6353 ... columns=columns)
6354 >>> df
6355 speed species
6356 max type
6357 class name
6358 bird falcon 389.0 fly
6359 parrot 24.0 fly
6360 mammal lion 80.5 run
6361 monkey NaN jump
6362
6363 Using the `names` parameter, choose a name for the index column:
6364
6365 >>> df.reset_index(names=['classes', 'names'])
6366 classes names speed species
6367 max type
6368 0 bird falcon 389.0 fly
6369 1 bird parrot 24.0 fly
6370 2 mammal lion 80.5 run
6371 3 mammal monkey NaN jump
6372
6373 If the index has multiple levels, we can reset a subset of them:
6374
6375 >>> df.reset_index(level='class')
6376 class speed species
6377 max type
6378 name
6379 falcon bird 389.0 fly
6380 parrot bird 24.0 fly
6381 lion mammal 80.5 run
6382 monkey mammal NaN jump
6383
6384 If we are not dropping the index, by default, it is placed in the top
6385 level. We can place it in another level:
6386
6387 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1)
6388 speed species
6389 class max type
6390 name
6391 falcon bird 389.0 fly
6392 parrot bird 24.0 fly
6393 lion mammal 80.5 run
6394 monkey mammal NaN jump
6395
6396 When the index is inserted under another level, we can specify under
6397 which one with the parameter `col_fill`:
6398
6399 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1, col_fill='species')
6400 species speed species
6401 class max type
6402 name
6403 falcon bird 389.0 fly
6404 parrot bird 24.0 fly
6405 lion mammal 80.5 run
6406 monkey mammal NaN jump
6407
6408 If we specify a nonexistent level for `col_fill`, it is created:
6409
6410 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1, col_fill='genus')
6411 genus speed species
6412 class max type
6413 name
6414 falcon bird 389.0 fly
6415 parrot bird 24.0 fly
6416 lion mammal 80.5 run
6417 monkey mammal NaN jump
6418 """
6419 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
6420 self._check_inplace_and_allows_duplicate_labels(inplace)
6421 if inplace:
6422 new_obj = self
6423 else:
6424 new_obj = self.copy(deep=None)
6425 if allow_duplicates is not lib.no_default:
6426 allow_duplicates = validate_bool_kwarg(allow_duplicates, "allow_duplicates")
6427
6428 new_index = default_index(len(new_obj))
6429 if level is not None:
6430 if not isinstance(level, (tuple, list)):
6431 level = [level]
6432 level = [self.index._get_level_number(lev) for lev in level]
6433 if len(level) < self.index.nlevels:
6434 new_index = self.index.droplevel(level)
6435
6436 if not drop:
6437 to_insert: Iterable[tuple[Any, Any | None]]
6438
6439 default = "index" if "index" not in self else "level_0"
6440 names = self.index._get_default_index_names(names, default)
6441
6442 if isinstance(self.index, MultiIndex):
6443 to_insert = zip(self.index.levels, self.index.codes)
6444 else:
6445 to_insert = ((self.index, None),)
6446
6447 multi_col = isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex)
6448 for i, (lev, lab) in reversed(list(enumerate(to_insert))):
6449 if level is not None and i not in level:
6450 continue
6451 name = names[i]
6452 if multi_col:
6453 col_name = list(name) if isinstance(name, tuple) else [name]
6454 if col_fill is None:
6455 if len(col_name) not in (1, self.columns.nlevels):
6456 raise ValueError(
6457 "col_fill=None is incompatible "
6458 f"with incomplete column name {name}"
6459 )
6460 col_fill = col_name[0]
6461
6462 lev_num = self.columns._get_level_number(col_level)
6463 name_lst = [col_fill] * lev_num + col_name
6464 missing = self.columns.nlevels - len(name_lst)
6465 name_lst += [col_fill] * missing
6466 name = tuple(name_lst)
6467
6468 # to ndarray and maybe infer different dtype
6469 level_values = lev._values
6470 if level_values.dtype == np.object_:
6471 level_values = lib.maybe_convert_objects(level_values)
6472
6473 if lab is not None:
6474 # if we have the codes, extract the values with a mask
6475 level_values = algorithms.take(
6476 level_values, lab, allow_fill=True, fill_value=lev._na_value
6477 )
6478
6479 new_obj.insert(
6480 0,
6481 name,
6482 level_values,
6483 allow_duplicates=allow_duplicates,
6484 )
6485
6486 new_obj.index = new_index
6487 if not inplace:
6488 return new_obj
6489
6490 return None
6491
6492 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
6493 # Reindex-based selection methods
6494
6495 @doc(NDFrame.isna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
6496 def isna(self) -> DataFrame:
6497 res_mgr = self._mgr.isna(func=isna)
6498 result = self._constructor_from_mgr(res_mgr, axes=res_mgr.axes)
6499 return result.__finalize__(self, method="isna")
6500
6501 @doc(NDFrame.isna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
6502 def isnull(self) -> DataFrame:
6503 """
6504 DataFrame.isnull is an alias for DataFrame.isna.
6505 """
6506 return self.isna()
6507
6508 @doc(NDFrame.notna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
6509 def notna(self) -> DataFrame:
6510 return ~self.isna()
6511
6512 @doc(NDFrame.notna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
6513 def notnull(self) -> DataFrame:
6514 """
6515 DataFrame.notnull is an alias for DataFrame.notna.
6516 """
6517 return ~self.isna()
6518
6519 @overload
6520 def dropna(
6521 self,
6522 *,
6523 axis: Axis = ...,
6524 how: AnyAll | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6525 thresh: int | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6526 subset: IndexLabel = ...,
6527 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
6528 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6529 ) -> DataFrame:
6530 ...
6531
6532 @overload
6533 def dropna(
6534 self,
6535 *,
6536 axis: Axis = ...,
6537 how: AnyAll | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6538 thresh: int | lib.NoDefault = ...,
6539 subset: IndexLabel = ...,
6540 inplace: Literal[True],
6541 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6542 ) -> None:
6543 ...
6544
6545 def dropna(
6546 self,
6547 *,
6548 axis: Axis = 0,
6549 how: AnyAll | lib.NoDefault = lib.no_default,
6550 thresh: int | lib.NoDefault = lib.no_default,
6551 subset: IndexLabel | None = None,
6552 inplace: bool = False,
6553 ignore_index: bool = False,
6554 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6555 """
6556 Remove missing values.
6557
6558 See the :ref:`User Guide <missing_data>` for more on which values are
6559 considered missing, and how to work with missing data.
6560
6561 Parameters
6562 ----------
6563 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
6564 Determine if rows or columns which contain missing values are
6565 removed.
6566
6567 * 0, or 'index' : Drop rows which contain missing values.
6568 * 1, or 'columns' : Drop columns which contain missing value.
6569
6570 Only a single axis is allowed.
6571
6572 how : {'any', 'all'}, default 'any'
6573 Determine if row or column is removed from DataFrame, when we have
6574 at least one NA or all NA.
6575
6576 * 'any' : If any NA values are present, drop that row or column.
6577 * 'all' : If all values are NA, drop that row or column.
6578
6579 thresh : int, optional
6580 Require that many non-NA values. Cannot be combined with how.
6581 subset : column label or sequence of labels, optional
6582 Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows
6583 these would be a list of columns to include.
6584 inplace : bool, default False
6585 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
6586 ignore_index : bool, default ``False``
6587 If ``True``, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
6588
6589 .. versionadded:: 2.0.0
6590
6591 Returns
6592 -------
6593 DataFrame or None
6594 DataFrame with NA entries dropped from it or None if ``inplace=True``.
6595
6596 See Also
6597 --------
6598 DataFrame.isna: Indicate missing values.
6599 DataFrame.notna : Indicate existing (non-missing) values.
6600 DataFrame.fillna : Replace missing values.
6601 Series.dropna : Drop missing values.
6602 Index.dropna : Drop missing indices.
6603
6604 Examples
6605 --------
6606 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"name": ['Alfred', 'Batman', 'Catwoman'],
6607 ... "toy": [np.nan, 'Batmobile', 'Bullwhip'],
6608 ... "born": [pd.NaT, pd.Timestamp("1940-04-25"),
6609 ... pd.NaT]})
6610 >>> df
6611 name toy born
6612 0 Alfred NaN NaT
6613 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
6614 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
6615
6616 Drop the rows where at least one element is missing.
6617
6618 >>> df.dropna()
6619 name toy born
6620 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
6621
6622 Drop the columns where at least one element is missing.
6623
6624 >>> df.dropna(axis='columns')
6625 name
6626 0 Alfred
6627 1 Batman
6628 2 Catwoman
6629
6630 Drop the rows where all elements are missing.
6631
6632 >>> df.dropna(how='all')
6633 name toy born
6634 0 Alfred NaN NaT
6635 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
6636 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
6637
6638 Keep only the rows with at least 2 non-NA values.
6639
6640 >>> df.dropna(thresh=2)
6641 name toy born
6642 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
6643 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
6644
6645 Define in which columns to look for missing values.
6646
6647 >>> df.dropna(subset=['name', 'toy'])
6648 name toy born
6649 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
6650 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
6651 """
6652 if (how is not lib.no_default) and (thresh is not lib.no_default):
6653 raise TypeError(
6654 "You cannot set both the how and thresh arguments at the same time."
6655 )
6656
6657 if how is lib.no_default:
6658 how = "any"
6659
6660 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
6661 if isinstance(axis, (tuple, list)):
6662 # GH20987
6663 raise TypeError("supplying multiple axes to axis is no longer supported.")
6664
6665 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
6666 agg_axis = 1 - axis
6667
6668 agg_obj = self
6669 if subset is not None:
6670 # subset needs to be list
6671 if not is_list_like(subset):
6672 subset = [subset]
6673 ax = self._get_axis(agg_axis)
6674 indices = ax.get_indexer_for(subset)
6675 check = indices == -1
6676 if check.any():
6677 raise KeyError(np.array(subset)[check].tolist())
6678 agg_obj = self.take(indices, axis=agg_axis)
6679
6680 if thresh is not lib.no_default:
6681 count = agg_obj.count(axis=agg_axis)
6682 mask = count >= thresh
6683 elif how == "any":
6684 # faster equivalent to 'agg_obj.count(agg_axis) == self.shape[agg_axis]'
6685 mask = notna(agg_obj).all(axis=agg_axis, bool_only=False)
6686 elif how == "all":
6687 # faster equivalent to 'agg_obj.count(agg_axis) > 0'
6688 mask = notna(agg_obj).any(axis=agg_axis, bool_only=False)
6689 else:
6690 raise ValueError(f"invalid how option: {how}")
6691
6692 if np.all(mask):
6693 result = self.copy(deep=None)
6694 else:
6695 result = self.loc(axis=axis)[mask]
6696
6697 if ignore_index:
6698 result.index = default_index(len(result))
6699
6700 if not inplace:
6701 return result
6702 self._update_inplace(result)
6703 return None
6704
6705 @overload
6706 def drop_duplicates(
6707 self,
6708 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = ...,
6709 *,
6710 keep: DropKeep = ...,
6711 inplace: Literal[True],
6712 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6713 ) -> None:
6714 ...
6715
6716 @overload
6717 def drop_duplicates(
6718 self,
6719 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = ...,
6720 *,
6721 keep: DropKeep = ...,
6722 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
6723 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6724 ) -> DataFrame:
6725 ...
6726
6727 @overload
6728 def drop_duplicates(
6729 self,
6730 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = ...,
6731 *,
6732 keep: DropKeep = ...,
6733 inplace: bool = ...,
6734 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6735 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6736 ...
6737
6738 def drop_duplicates(
6739 self,
6740 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6741 *,
6742 keep: DropKeep = "first",
6743 inplace: bool = False,
6744 ignore_index: bool = False,
6745 ) -> DataFrame | None:
6746 """
6747 Return DataFrame with duplicate rows removed.
6748
6749 Considering certain columns is optional. Indexes, including time indexes
6750 are ignored.
6751
6752 Parameters
6753 ----------
6754 subset : column label or sequence of labels, optional
6755 Only consider certain columns for identifying duplicates, by
6756 default use all of the columns.
6757 keep : {'first', 'last', ``False``}, default 'first'
6758 Determines which duplicates (if any) to keep.
6759
6760 - 'first' : Drop duplicates except for the first occurrence.
6761 - 'last' : Drop duplicates except for the last occurrence.
6762 - ``False`` : Drop all duplicates.
6763
6764 inplace : bool, default ``False``
6765 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
6766 ignore_index : bool, default ``False``
6767 If ``True``, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
6768
6769 Returns
6770 -------
6771 DataFrame or None
6772 DataFrame with duplicates removed or None if ``inplace=True``.
6773
6774 See Also
6775 --------
6776 DataFrame.value_counts: Count unique combinations of columns.
6777
6778 Examples
6779 --------
6780 Consider dataset containing ramen rating.
6781
6782 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
6783 ... 'brand': ['Yum Yum', 'Yum Yum', 'Indomie', 'Indomie', 'Indomie'],
6784 ... 'style': ['cup', 'cup', 'cup', 'pack', 'pack'],
6785 ... 'rating': [4, 4, 3.5, 15, 5]
6786 ... })
6787 >>> df
6788 brand style rating
6789 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6790 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6791 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6792 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6793 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6794
6795 By default, it removes duplicate rows based on all columns.
6796
6797 >>> df.drop_duplicates()
6798 brand style rating
6799 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6800 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6801 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6802 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6803
6804 To remove duplicates on specific column(s), use ``subset``.
6805
6806 >>> df.drop_duplicates(subset=['brand'])
6807 brand style rating
6808 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6809 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6810
6811 To remove duplicates and keep last occurrences, use ``keep``.
6812
6813 >>> df.drop_duplicates(subset=['brand', 'style'], keep='last')
6814 brand style rating
6815 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6816 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6817 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6818 """
6819 if self.empty:
6820 return self.copy(deep=None)
6821
6822 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
6823 ignore_index = validate_bool_kwarg(ignore_index, "ignore_index")
6824
6825 result = self[-self.duplicated(subset, keep=keep)]
6826 if ignore_index:
6827 result.index = default_index(len(result))
6828
6829 if inplace:
6830 self._update_inplace(result)
6831 return None
6832 else:
6833 return result
6834
6835 def duplicated(
6836 self,
6837 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6838 keep: DropKeep = "first",
6839 ) -> Series:
6840 """
6841 Return boolean Series denoting duplicate rows.
6842
6843 Considering certain columns is optional.
6844
6845 Parameters
6846 ----------
6847 subset : column label or sequence of labels, optional
6848 Only consider certain columns for identifying duplicates, by
6849 default use all of the columns.
6850 keep : {'first', 'last', False}, default 'first'
6851 Determines which duplicates (if any) to mark.
6852
6853 - ``first`` : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the first occurrence.
6854 - ``last`` : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the last occurrence.
6855 - False : Mark all duplicates as ``True``.
6856
6857 Returns
6858 -------
6859 Series
6860 Boolean series for each duplicated rows.
6861
6862 See Also
6863 --------
6864 Index.duplicated : Equivalent method on index.
6865 Series.duplicated : Equivalent method on Series.
6866 Series.drop_duplicates : Remove duplicate values from Series.
6867 DataFrame.drop_duplicates : Remove duplicate values from DataFrame.
6868
6869 Examples
6870 --------
6871 Consider dataset containing ramen rating.
6872
6873 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
6874 ... 'brand': ['Yum Yum', 'Yum Yum', 'Indomie', 'Indomie', 'Indomie'],
6875 ... 'style': ['cup', 'cup', 'cup', 'pack', 'pack'],
6876 ... 'rating': [4, 4, 3.5, 15, 5]
6877 ... })
6878 >>> df
6879 brand style rating
6880 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6881 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6882 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6883 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6884 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6885
6886 By default, for each set of duplicated values, the first occurrence
6887 is set on False and all others on True.
6888
6889 >>> df.duplicated()
6890 0 False
6891 1 True
6892 2 False
6893 3 False
6894 4 False
6895 dtype: bool
6896
6897 By using 'last', the last occurrence of each set of duplicated values
6898 is set on False and all others on True.
6899
6900 >>> df.duplicated(keep='last')
6901 0 True
6902 1 False
6903 2 False
6904 3 False
6905 4 False
6906 dtype: bool
6907
6908 By setting ``keep`` on False, all duplicates are True.
6909
6910 >>> df.duplicated(keep=False)
6911 0 True
6912 1 True
6913 2 False
6914 3 False
6915 4 False
6916 dtype: bool
6917
6918 To find duplicates on specific column(s), use ``subset``.
6919
6920 >>> df.duplicated(subset=['brand'])
6921 0 False
6922 1 True
6923 2 False
6924 3 True
6925 4 True
6926 dtype: bool
6927 """
6928
6929 if self.empty:
6930 return self._constructor_sliced(dtype=bool)
6931
6932 def f(vals) -> tuple[np.ndarray, int]:
6933 labels, shape = algorithms.factorize(vals, size_hint=len(self))
6934 return labels.astype("i8", copy=False), len(shape)
6935
6936 if subset is None:
6937 # https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/28770
6938 # Incompatible types in assignment (expression has type "Index", variable
6939 # has type "Sequence[Any]")
6940 subset = self.columns # type: ignore[assignment]
6941 elif (
6942 not np.iterable(subset)
6943 or isinstance(subset, str)
6944 or isinstance(subset, tuple)
6945 and subset in self.columns
6946 ):
6947 subset = (subset,)
6948
6949 # needed for mypy since can't narrow types using np.iterable
6950 subset = cast(Sequence, subset)
6951
6952 # Verify all columns in subset exist in the queried dataframe
6953 # Otherwise, raise a KeyError, same as if you try to __getitem__ with a
6954 # key that doesn't exist.
6955 diff = set(subset) - set(self.columns)
6956 if diff:
6957 raise KeyError(Index(diff))
6958
6959 if len(subset) == 1 and self.columns.is_unique:
6960 # GH#45236 This is faster than get_group_index below
6961 result = self[subset[0]].duplicated(keep)
6962 result.name = None
6963 else:
6964 vals = (col.values for name, col in self.items() if name in subset)
6965 labels, shape = map(list, zip(*map(f, vals)))
6966
6967 ids = get_group_index(labels, tuple(shape), sort=False, xnull=False)
6968 result = self._constructor_sliced(duplicated(ids, keep), index=self.index)
6969 return result.__finalize__(self, method="duplicated")
6970
6971 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
6972 # Sorting
6973 # error: Signature of "sort_values" incompatible with supertype "NDFrame"
6974 @overload # type: ignore[override]
6975 def sort_values(
6976 self,
6977 by: IndexLabel,
6978 *,
6979 axis: Axis = ...,
6980 ascending=...,
6981 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
6982 kind: SortKind = ...,
6983 na_position: NaPosition = ...,
6984 ignore_index: bool = ...,
6985 key: ValueKeyFunc = ...,
6986 ) -> DataFrame:
6987 ...
6988
6989 @overload
6990 def sort_values(
6991 self,
6992 by: IndexLabel,
6993 *,
6994 axis: Axis = ...,
6995 ascending=...,
6996 inplace: Literal[True],
6997 kind: SortKind = ...,
6998 na_position: str = ...,
6999 ignore_index: bool = ...,
7000 key: ValueKeyFunc = ...,
7001 ) -> None:
7002 ...
7003
7004 def sort_values(
7005 self,
7006 by: IndexLabel,
7007 *,
7008 axis: Axis = 0,
7009 ascending: bool | list[bool] | tuple[bool, ...] = True,
7010 inplace: bool = False,
7011 kind: SortKind = "quicksort",
7012 na_position: str = "last",
7013 ignore_index: bool = False,
7014 key: ValueKeyFunc | None = None,
7015 ) -> DataFrame | None:
7016 """
7017 Sort by the values along either axis.
7018
7019 Parameters
7020 ----------
7021 by : str or list of str
7022 Name or list of names to sort by.
7023
7024 - if `axis` is 0 or `'index'` then `by` may contain index
7025 levels and/or column labels.
7026 - if `axis` is 1 or `'columns'` then `by` may contain column
7027 levels and/or index labels.
7028 axis : "{0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}", default 0
7029 Axis to be sorted.
7030 ascending : bool or list of bool, default True
7031 Sort ascending vs. descending. Specify list for multiple sort
7032 orders. If this is a list of bools, must match the length of
7033 the by.
7034 inplace : bool, default False
7035 If True, perform operation in-place.
7036 kind : {'quicksort', 'mergesort', 'heapsort', 'stable'}, default 'quicksort'
7037 Choice of sorting algorithm. See also :func:`numpy.sort` for more
7038 information. `mergesort` and `stable` are the only stable algorithms. For
7039 DataFrames, this option is only applied when sorting on a single
7040 column or label.
7041 na_position : {'first', 'last'}, default 'last'
7042 Puts NaNs at the beginning if `first`; `last` puts NaNs at the
7043 end.
7044 ignore_index : bool, default False
7045 If True, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
7046 key : callable, optional
7047 Apply the key function to the values
7048 before sorting. This is similar to the `key` argument in the
7049 builtin :meth:`sorted` function, with the notable difference that
7050 this `key` function should be *vectorized*. It should expect a
7051 ``Series`` and return a Series with the same shape as the input.
7052 It will be applied to each column in `by` independently.
7053
7054 Returns
7055 -------
7056 DataFrame or None
7057 DataFrame with sorted values or None if ``inplace=True``.
7058
7059 See Also
7060 --------
7061 DataFrame.sort_index : Sort a DataFrame by the index.
7062 Series.sort_values : Similar method for a Series.
7063
7064 Examples
7065 --------
7066 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
7067 ... 'col1': ['A', 'A', 'B', np.nan, 'D', 'C'],
7068 ... 'col2': [2, 1, 9, 8, 7, 4],
7069 ... 'col3': [0, 1, 9, 4, 2, 3],
7070 ... 'col4': ['a', 'B', 'c', 'D', 'e', 'F']
7071 ... })
7072 >>> df
7073 col1 col2 col3 col4
7074 0 A 2 0 a
7075 1 A 1 1 B
7076 2 B 9 9 c
7077 3 NaN 8 4 D
7078 4 D 7 2 e
7079 5 C 4 3 F
7080
7081 Sort by col1
7082
7083 >>> df.sort_values(by=['col1'])
7084 col1 col2 col3 col4
7085 0 A 2 0 a
7086 1 A 1 1 B
7087 2 B 9 9 c
7088 5 C 4 3 F
7089 4 D 7 2 e
7090 3 NaN 8 4 D
7091
7092 Sort by multiple columns
7093
7094 >>> df.sort_values(by=['col1', 'col2'])
7095 col1 col2 col3 col4
7096 1 A 1 1 B
7097 0 A 2 0 a
7098 2 B 9 9 c
7099 5 C 4 3 F
7100 4 D 7 2 e
7101 3 NaN 8 4 D
7102
7103 Sort Descending
7104
7105 >>> df.sort_values(by='col1', ascending=False)
7106 col1 col2 col3 col4
7107 4 D 7 2 e
7108 5 C 4 3 F
7109 2 B 9 9 c
7110 0 A 2 0 a
7111 1 A 1 1 B
7112 3 NaN 8 4 D
7113
7114 Putting NAs first
7115
7116 >>> df.sort_values(by='col1', ascending=False, na_position='first')
7117 col1 col2 col3 col4
7118 3 NaN 8 4 D
7119 4 D 7 2 e
7120 5 C 4 3 F
7121 2 B 9 9 c
7122 0 A 2 0 a
7123 1 A 1 1 B
7124
7125 Sorting with a key function
7126
7127 >>> df.sort_values(by='col4', key=lambda col: col.str.lower())
7128 col1 col2 col3 col4
7129 0 A 2 0 a
7130 1 A 1 1 B
7131 2 B 9 9 c
7132 3 NaN 8 4 D
7133 4 D 7 2 e
7134 5 C 4 3 F
7135
7136 Natural sort with the key argument,
7137 using the `natsort <https://github.com/SethMMorton/natsort>` package.
7138
7139 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
7140 ... "time": ['0hr', '128hr', '72hr', '48hr', '96hr'],
7141 ... "value": [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]
7142 ... })
7143 >>> df
7144 time value
7145 0 0hr 10
7146 1 128hr 20
7147 2 72hr 30
7148 3 48hr 40
7149 4 96hr 50
7150 >>> from natsort import index_natsorted
7151 >>> df.sort_values(
7152 ... by="time",
7153 ... key=lambda x: np.argsort(index_natsorted(df["time"]))
7154 ... )
7155 time value
7156 0 0hr 10
7157 3 48hr 40
7158 2 72hr 30
7159 4 96hr 50
7160 1 128hr 20
7161 """
7162 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
7163 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
7164 ascending = validate_ascending(ascending)
7165 if not isinstance(by, list):
7166 by = [by]
7167 # error: Argument 1 to "len" has incompatible type "Union[bool, List[bool]]";
7168 # expected "Sized"
7169 if is_sequence(ascending) and (
7170 len(by) != len(ascending) # type: ignore[arg-type]
7171 ):
7172 # error: Argument 1 to "len" has incompatible type "Union[bool,
7173 # List[bool]]"; expected "Sized"
7174 raise ValueError(
7175 f"Length of ascending ({len(ascending)})" # type: ignore[arg-type]
7176 f" != length of by ({len(by)})"
7177 )
7178 if len(by) > 1:
7179 keys = [self._get_label_or_level_values(x, axis=axis) for x in by]
7180
7181 # need to rewrap columns in Series to apply key function
7182 if key is not None:
7183 # error: List comprehension has incompatible type List[Series];
7184 # expected List[ndarray]
7185 keys = [
7186 Series(k, name=name) # type: ignore[misc]
7187 for (k, name) in zip(keys, by)
7188 ]
7189
7190 indexer = lexsort_indexer(
7191 keys, orders=ascending, na_position=na_position, key=key
7192 )
7193 elif len(by):
7194 # len(by) == 1
7195
7196 k = self._get_label_or_level_values(by[0], axis=axis)
7197
7198 # need to rewrap column in Series to apply key function
7199 if key is not None:
7200 # error: Incompatible types in assignment (expression has type
7201 # "Series", variable has type "ndarray")
7202 k = Series(k, name=by[0]) # type: ignore[assignment]
7203
7204 if isinstance(ascending, (tuple, list)):
7205 ascending = ascending[0]
7206
7207 indexer = nargsort(
7208 k, kind=kind, ascending=ascending, na_position=na_position, key=key
7209 )
7210 else:
7211 if inplace:
7212 return self._update_inplace(self)
7213 else:
7214 return self.copy(deep=None)
7215
7216 if is_range_indexer(indexer, len(indexer)):
7217 result = self.copy(deep=(not inplace and not using_copy_on_write()))
7218 if ignore_index:
7219 result.index = default_index(len(result))
7220
7221 if inplace:
7222 return self._update_inplace(result)
7223 else:
7224 return result
7225
7226 new_data = self._mgr.take(
7227 indexer, axis=self._get_block_manager_axis(axis), verify=False
7228 )
7229
7230 if ignore_index:
7231 new_data.set_axis(
7232 self._get_block_manager_axis(axis), default_index(len(indexer))
7233 )
7234
7235 result = self._constructor_from_mgr(new_data, axes=new_data.axes)
7236 if inplace:
7237 return self._update_inplace(result)
7238 else:
7239 return result.__finalize__(self, method="sort_values")
7240
7241 @overload
7242 def sort_index(
7243 self,
7244 *,
7245 axis: Axis = ...,
7246 level: IndexLabel = ...,
7247 ascending: bool | Sequence[bool] = ...,
7248 inplace: Literal[True],
7249 kind: SortKind = ...,
7250 na_position: NaPosition = ...,
7251 sort_remaining: bool = ...,
7252 ignore_index: bool = ...,
7253 key: IndexKeyFunc = ...,
7254 ) -> None:
7255 ...
7256
7257 @overload
7258 def sort_index(
7259 self,
7260 *,
7261 axis: Axis = ...,
7262 level: IndexLabel = ...,
7263 ascending: bool | Sequence[bool] = ...,
7264 inplace: Literal[False] = ...,
7265 kind: SortKind = ...,
7266 na_position: NaPosition = ...,
7267 sort_remaining: bool = ...,
7268 ignore_index: bool = ...,
7269 key: IndexKeyFunc = ...,
7270 ) -> DataFrame:
7271 ...
7272
7273 @overload
7274 def sort_index(
7275 self,
7276 *,
7277 axis: Axis = ...,
7278 level: IndexLabel = ...,
7279 ascending: bool | Sequence[bool] = ...,
7280 inplace: bool = ...,
7281 kind: SortKind = ...,
7282 na_position: NaPosition = ...,
7283 sort_remaining: bool = ...,
7284 ignore_index: bool = ...,
7285 key: IndexKeyFunc = ...,
7286 ) -> DataFrame | None:
7287 ...
7288
7289 def sort_index(
7290 self,
7291 *,
7292 axis: Axis = 0,
7293 level: IndexLabel | None = None,
7294 ascending: bool | Sequence[bool] = True,
7295 inplace: bool = False,
7296 kind: SortKind = "quicksort",
7297 na_position: NaPosition = "last",
7298 sort_remaining: bool = True,
7299 ignore_index: bool = False,
7300 key: IndexKeyFunc | None = None,
7301 ) -> DataFrame | None:
7302 """
7303 Sort object by labels (along an axis).
7304
7305 Returns a new DataFrame sorted by label if `inplace` argument is
7306 ``False``, otherwise updates the original DataFrame and returns None.
7307
7308 Parameters
7309 ----------
7310 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
7311 The axis along which to sort. The value 0 identifies the rows,
7312 and 1 identifies the columns.
7313 level : int or level name or list of ints or list of level names
7314 If not None, sort on values in specified index level(s).
7315 ascending : bool or list-like of bools, default True
7316 Sort ascending vs. descending. When the index is a MultiIndex the
7317 sort direction can be controlled for each level individually.
7318 inplace : bool, default False
7319 Whether to modify the DataFrame rather than creating a new one.
7320 kind : {'quicksort', 'mergesort', 'heapsort', 'stable'}, default 'quicksort'
7321 Choice of sorting algorithm. See also :func:`numpy.sort` for more
7322 information. `mergesort` and `stable` are the only stable algorithms. For
7323 DataFrames, this option is only applied when sorting on a single
7324 column or label.
7325 na_position : {'first', 'last'}, default 'last'
7326 Puts NaNs at the beginning if `first`; `last` puts NaNs at the end.
7327 Not implemented for MultiIndex.
7328 sort_remaining : bool, default True
7329 If True and sorting by level and index is multilevel, sort by other
7330 levels too (in order) after sorting by specified level.
7331 ignore_index : bool, default False
7332 If True, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
7333 key : callable, optional
7334 If not None, apply the key function to the index values
7335 before sorting. This is similar to the `key` argument in the
7336 builtin :meth:`sorted` function, with the notable difference that
7337 this `key` function should be *vectorized*. It should expect an
7338 ``Index`` and return an ``Index`` of the same shape. For MultiIndex
7339 inputs, the key is applied *per level*.
7340
7341 Returns
7342 -------
7343 DataFrame or None
7344 The original DataFrame sorted by the labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
7345
7346 See Also
7347 --------
7348 Series.sort_index : Sort Series by the index.
7349 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the value.
7350 Series.sort_values : Sort Series by the value.
7351
7352 Examples
7353 --------
7354 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], index=[100, 29, 234, 1, 150],
7355 ... columns=['A'])
7356 >>> df.sort_index()
7357 A
7358 1 4
7359 29 2
7360 100 1
7361 150 5
7362 234 3
7363
7364 By default, it sorts in ascending order, to sort in descending order,
7365 use ``ascending=False``
7366
7367 >>> df.sort_index(ascending=False)
7368 A
7369 234 3
7370 150 5
7371 100 1
7372 29 2
7373 1 4
7374
7375 A key function can be specified which is applied to the index before
7376 sorting. For a ``MultiIndex`` this is applied to each level separately.
7377
7378 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3, 4]}, index=['A', 'b', 'C', 'd'])
7379 >>> df.sort_index(key=lambda x: x.str.lower())
7380 a
7381 A 1
7382 b 2
7383 C 3
7384 d 4
7385 """
7386 return super().sort_index(
7387 axis=axis,
7388 level=level,
7389 ascending=ascending,
7390 inplace=inplace,
7391 kind=kind,
7392 na_position=na_position,
7393 sort_remaining=sort_remaining,
7394 ignore_index=ignore_index,
7395 key=key,
7396 )
7397
7398 def value_counts(
7399 self,
7400 subset: IndexLabel | None = None,
7401 normalize: bool = False,
7402 sort: bool = True,
7403 ascending: bool = False,
7404 dropna: bool = True,
7405 ) -> Series:
7406 """
7407 Return a Series containing the frequency of each distinct row in the Dataframe.
7408
7409 Parameters
7410 ----------
7411 subset : label or list of labels, optional
7412 Columns to use when counting unique combinations.
7413 normalize : bool, default False
7414 Return proportions rather than frequencies.
7415 sort : bool, default True
7416 Sort by frequencies when True. Sort by DataFrame column values when False.
7417 ascending : bool, default False
7418 Sort in ascending order.
7419 dropna : bool, default True
7420 Don't include counts of rows that contain NA values.
7421
7422 .. versionadded:: 1.3.0
7423
7424 Returns
7425 -------
7426 Series
7427
7428 See Also
7429 --------
7430 Series.value_counts: Equivalent method on Series.
7431
7432 Notes
7433 -----
7434 The returned Series will have a MultiIndex with one level per input
7435 column but an Index (non-multi) for a single label. By default, rows
7436 that contain any NA values are omitted from the result. By default,
7437 the resulting Series will be in descending order so that the first
7438 element is the most frequently-occurring row.
7439
7440 Examples
7441 --------
7442 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'num_legs': [2, 4, 4, 6],
7443 ... 'num_wings': [2, 0, 0, 0]},
7444 ... index=['falcon', 'dog', 'cat', 'ant'])
7445 >>> df
7446 num_legs num_wings
7447 falcon 2 2
7448 dog 4 0
7449 cat 4 0
7450 ant 6 0
7451
7452 >>> df.value_counts()
7453 num_legs num_wings
7454 4 0 2
7455 2 2 1
7456 6 0 1
7457 Name: count, dtype: int64
7458
7459 >>> df.value_counts(sort=False)
7460 num_legs num_wings
7461 2 2 1
7462 4 0 2
7463 6 0 1
7464 Name: count, dtype: int64
7465
7466 >>> df.value_counts(ascending=True)
7467 num_legs num_wings
7468 2 2 1
7469 6 0 1
7470 4 0 2
7471 Name: count, dtype: int64
7472
7473 >>> df.value_counts(normalize=True)
7474 num_legs num_wings
7475 4 0 0.50
7476 2 2 0.25
7477 6 0 0.25
7478 Name: proportion, dtype: float64
7479
7480 With `dropna` set to `False` we can also count rows with NA values.
7481
7482 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'first_name': ['John', 'Anne', 'John', 'Beth'],
7483 ... 'middle_name': ['Smith', pd.NA, pd.NA, 'Louise']})
7484 >>> df
7485 first_name middle_name
7486 0 John Smith
7487 1 Anne <NA>
7488 2 John <NA>
7489 3 Beth Louise
7490
7491 >>> df.value_counts()
7492 first_name middle_name
7493 Beth Louise 1
7494 John Smith 1
7495 Name: count, dtype: int64
7496
7497 >>> df.value_counts(dropna=False)
7498 first_name middle_name
7499 Anne NaN 1
7500 Beth Louise 1
7501 John Smith 1
7502 NaN 1
7503 Name: count, dtype: int64
7504
7505 >>> df.value_counts("first_name")
7506 first_name
7507 John 2
7508 Anne 1
7509 Beth 1
7510 Name: count, dtype: int64
7511 """
7512 if subset is None:
7513 subset = self.columns.tolist()
7514
7515 name = "proportion" if normalize else "count"
7516 counts = self.groupby(subset, dropna=dropna, observed=False)._grouper.size()
7517 counts.name = name
7518
7519 if sort:
7520 counts = counts.sort_values(ascending=ascending)
7521 if normalize:
7522 counts /= counts.sum()
7523
7524 # Force MultiIndex for a list_like subset with a single column
7525 if is_list_like(subset) and len(subset) == 1: # type: ignore[arg-type]
7526 counts.index = MultiIndex.from_arrays(
7527 [counts.index], names=[counts.index.name]
7528 )
7529
7530 return counts
7531
7532 def nlargest(
7533 self, n: int, columns: IndexLabel, keep: NsmallestNlargestKeep = "first"
7534 ) -> DataFrame:
7535 """
7536 Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in descending order.
7537
7538 Return the first `n` rows with the largest values in `columns`, in
7539 descending order. The columns that are not specified are returned as
7540 well, but not used for ordering.
7541
7542 This method is equivalent to
7543 ``df.sort_values(columns, ascending=False).head(n)``, but more
7544 performant.
7545
7546 Parameters
7547 ----------
7548 n : int
7549 Number of rows to return.
7550 columns : label or list of labels
7551 Column label(s) to order by.
7552 keep : {'first', 'last', 'all'}, default 'first'
7553 Where there are duplicate values:
7554
7555 - ``first`` : prioritize the first occurrence(s)
7556 - ``last`` : prioritize the last occurrence(s)
7557 - ``all`` : keep all the ties of the smallest item even if it means
7558 selecting more than ``n`` items.
7559
7560 Returns
7561 -------
7562 DataFrame
7563 The first `n` rows ordered by the given columns in descending
7564 order.
7565
7566 See Also
7567 --------
7568 DataFrame.nsmallest : Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in
7569 ascending order.
7570 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the values.
7571 DataFrame.head : Return the first `n` rows without re-ordering.
7572
7573 Notes
7574 -----
7575 This function cannot be used with all column types. For example, when
7576 specifying columns with `object` or `category` dtypes, ``TypeError`` is
7577 raised.
7578
7579 Examples
7580 --------
7581 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'population': [59000000, 65000000, 434000,
7582 ... 434000, 434000, 337000, 11300,
7583 ... 11300, 11300],
7584 ... 'GDP': [1937894, 2583560 , 12011, 4520, 12128,
7585 ... 17036, 182, 38, 311],
7586 ... 'alpha-2': ["IT", "FR", "MT", "MV", "BN",
7587 ... "IS", "NR", "TV", "AI"]},
7588 ... index=["Italy", "France", "Malta",
7589 ... "Maldives", "Brunei", "Iceland",
7590 ... "Nauru", "Tuvalu", "Anguilla"])
7591 >>> df
7592 population GDP alpha-2
7593 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7594 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7595 Malta 434000 12011 MT
7596 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
7597 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7598 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
7599 Nauru 11300 182 NR
7600 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7601 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7602
7603 In the following example, we will use ``nlargest`` to select the three
7604 rows having the largest values in column "population".
7605
7606 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population')
7607 population GDP alpha-2
7608 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7609 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7610 Malta 434000 12011 MT
7611
7612 When using ``keep='last'``, ties are resolved in reverse order:
7613
7614 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population', keep='last')
7615 population GDP alpha-2
7616 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7617 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7618 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7619
7620 When using ``keep='all'``, the number of element kept can go beyond ``n``
7621 if there are duplicate values for the smallest element, all the
7622 ties are kept:
7623
7624 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population', keep='all')
7625 population GDP alpha-2
7626 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7627 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7628 Malta 434000 12011 MT
7629 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
7630 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7631
7632 However, ``nlargest`` does not keep ``n`` distinct largest elements:
7633
7634 >>> df.nlargest(5, 'population', keep='all')
7635 population GDP alpha-2
7636 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7637 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7638 Malta 434000 12011 MT
7639 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
7640 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7641
7642 To order by the largest values in column "population" and then "GDP",
7643 we can specify multiple columns like in the next example.
7644
7645 >>> df.nlargest(3, ['population', 'GDP'])
7646 population GDP alpha-2
7647 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7648 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7649 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7650 """
7651 return selectn.SelectNFrame(self, n=n, keep=keep, columns=columns).nlargest()
7652
7653 def nsmallest(
7654 self, n: int, columns: IndexLabel, keep: NsmallestNlargestKeep = "first"
7655 ) -> DataFrame:
7656 """
7657 Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in ascending order.
7658
7659 Return the first `n` rows with the smallest values in `columns`, in
7660 ascending order. The columns that are not specified are returned as
7661 well, but not used for ordering.
7662
7663 This method is equivalent to
7664 ``df.sort_values(columns, ascending=True).head(n)``, but more
7665 performant.
7666
7667 Parameters
7668 ----------
7669 n : int
7670 Number of items to retrieve.
7671 columns : list or str
7672 Column name or names to order by.
7673 keep : {'first', 'last', 'all'}, default 'first'
7674 Where there are duplicate values:
7675
7676 - ``first`` : take the first occurrence.
7677 - ``last`` : take the last occurrence.
7678 - ``all`` : keep all the ties of the largest item even if it means
7679 selecting more than ``n`` items.
7680
7681 Returns
7682 -------
7683 DataFrame
7684
7685 See Also
7686 --------
7687 DataFrame.nlargest : Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in
7688 descending order.
7689 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the values.
7690 DataFrame.head : Return the first `n` rows without re-ordering.
7691
7692 Examples
7693 --------
7694 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'population': [59000000, 65000000, 434000,
7695 ... 434000, 434000, 337000, 337000,
7696 ... 11300, 11300],
7697 ... 'GDP': [1937894, 2583560 , 12011, 4520, 12128,
7698 ... 17036, 182, 38, 311],
7699 ... 'alpha-2': ["IT", "FR", "MT", "MV", "BN",
7700 ... "IS", "NR", "TV", "AI"]},
7701 ... index=["Italy", "France", "Malta",
7702 ... "Maldives", "Brunei", "Iceland",
7703 ... "Nauru", "Tuvalu", "Anguilla"])
7704 >>> df
7705 population GDP alpha-2
7706 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
7707 France 65000000 2583560 FR
7708 Malta 434000 12011 MT
7709 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
7710 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
7711 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
7712 Nauru 337000 182 NR
7713 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7714 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7715
7716 In the following example, we will use ``nsmallest`` to select the
7717 three rows having the smallest values in column "population".
7718
7719 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population')
7720 population GDP alpha-2
7721 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7722 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7723 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
7724
7725 When using ``keep='last'``, ties are resolved in reverse order:
7726
7727 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population', keep='last')
7728 population GDP alpha-2
7729 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7730 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7731 Nauru 337000 182 NR
7732
7733 When using ``keep='all'``, the number of element kept can go beyond ``n``
7734 if there are duplicate values for the largest element, all the
7735 ties are kept.
7736
7737 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population', keep='all')
7738 population GDP alpha-2
7739 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7740 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7741 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
7742 Nauru 337000 182 NR
7743
7744 However, ``nsmallest`` does not keep ``n`` distinct
7745 smallest elements:
7746
7747 >>> df.nsmallest(4, 'population', keep='all')
7748 population GDP alpha-2
7749 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7750 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7751 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
7752 Nauru 337000 182 NR
7753
7754 To order by the smallest values in column "population" and then "GDP", we can
7755 specify multiple columns like in the next example.
7756
7757 >>> df.nsmallest(3, ['population', 'GDP'])
7758 population GDP alpha-2
7759 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
7760 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
7761 Nauru 337000 182 NR
7762 """
7763 return selectn.SelectNFrame(self, n=n, keep=keep, columns=columns).nsmallest()
7764
7765 @doc(
7766 Series.swaplevel,
7767 klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"],
7768 extra_params=dedent(
7769 """axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
7770 The axis to swap levels on. 0 or 'index' for row-wise, 1 or
7771 'columns' for column-wise."""
7772 ),
7773 examples=dedent(
7774 """\
7775 Examples
7776 --------
7777 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(
7778 ... {"Grade": ["A", "B", "A", "C"]},
7779 ... index=[
7780 ... ["Final exam", "Final exam", "Coursework", "Coursework"],
7781 ... ["History", "Geography", "History", "Geography"],
7782 ... ["January", "February", "March", "April"],
7783 ... ],
7784 ... )
7785 >>> df
7786 Grade
7787 Final exam History January A
7788 Geography February B
7789 Coursework History March A
7790 Geography April C
7791
7792 In the following example, we will swap the levels of the indices.
7793 Here, we will swap the levels column-wise, but levels can be swapped row-wise
7794 in a similar manner. Note that column-wise is the default behaviour.
7795 By not supplying any arguments for i and j, we swap the last and second to
7796 last indices.
7797
7798 >>> df.swaplevel()
7799 Grade
7800 Final exam January History A
7801 February Geography B
7802 Coursework March History A
7803 April Geography C
7804
7805 By supplying one argument, we can choose which index to swap the last
7806 index with. We can for example swap the first index with the last one as
7807 follows.
7808
7809 >>> df.swaplevel(0)
7810 Grade
7811 January History Final exam A
7812 February Geography Final exam B
7813 March History Coursework A
7814 April Geography Coursework C
7815
7816 We can also define explicitly which indices we want to swap by supplying values
7817 for both i and j. Here, we for example swap the first and second indices.
7818
7819 >>> df.swaplevel(0, 1)
7820 Grade
7821 History Final exam January A
7822 Geography Final exam February B
7823 History Coursework March A
7824 Geography Coursework April C"""
7825 ),
7826 )
7827 def swaplevel(self, i: Axis = -2, j: Axis = -1, axis: Axis = 0) -> DataFrame:
7828 result = self.copy(deep=None)
7829
7830 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
7831
7832 if not isinstance(result._get_axis(axis), MultiIndex): # pragma: no cover
7833 raise TypeError("Can only swap levels on a hierarchical axis.")
7834
7835 if axis == 0:
7836 assert isinstance(result.index, MultiIndex)
7837 result.index = result.index.swaplevel(i, j)
7838 else:
7839 assert isinstance(result.columns, MultiIndex)
7840 result.columns = result.columns.swaplevel(i, j)
7841 return result
7842
7843 def reorder_levels(self, order: Sequence[int | str], axis: Axis = 0) -> DataFrame:
7844 """
7845 Rearrange index levels using input order. May not drop or duplicate levels.
7846
7847 Parameters
7848 ----------
7849 order : list of int or list of str
7850 List representing new level order. Reference level by number
7851 (position) or by key (label).
7852 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
7853 Where to reorder levels.
7854
7855 Returns
7856 -------
7857 DataFrame
7858
7859 Examples
7860 --------
7861 >>> data = {
7862 ... "class": ["Mammals", "Mammals", "Reptiles"],
7863 ... "diet": ["Omnivore", "Carnivore", "Carnivore"],
7864 ... "species": ["Humans", "Dogs", "Snakes"],
7865 ... }
7866 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=["class", "diet", "species"])
7867 >>> df = df.set_index(["class", "diet"])
7868 >>> df
7869 species
7870 class diet
7871 Mammals Omnivore Humans
7872 Carnivore Dogs
7873 Reptiles Carnivore Snakes
7874
7875 Let's reorder the levels of the index:
7876
7877 >>> df.reorder_levels(["diet", "class"])
7878 species
7879 diet class
7880 Omnivore Mammals Humans
7881 Carnivore Mammals Dogs
7882 Reptiles Snakes
7883 """
7884 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
7885 if not isinstance(self._get_axis(axis), MultiIndex): # pragma: no cover
7886 raise TypeError("Can only reorder levels on a hierarchical axis.")
7887
7888 result = self.copy(deep=None)
7889
7890 if axis == 0:
7891 assert isinstance(result.index, MultiIndex)
7892 result.index = result.index.reorder_levels(order)
7893 else:
7894 assert isinstance(result.columns, MultiIndex)
7895 result.columns = result.columns.reorder_levels(order)
7896 return result
7897
7898 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
7899 # Arithmetic Methods
7900
7901 def _cmp_method(self, other, op):
7902 axis: Literal[1] = 1 # only relevant for Series other case
7903
7904 self, other = self._align_for_op(other, axis, flex=False, level=None)
7905
7906 # See GH#4537 for discussion of scalar op behavior
7907 new_data = self._dispatch_frame_op(other, op, axis=axis)
7908 return self._construct_result(new_data)
7909
7910 def _arith_method(self, other, op):
7911 if self._should_reindex_frame_op(other, op, 1, None, None):
7912 return self._arith_method_with_reindex(other, op)
7913
7914 axis: Literal[1] = 1 # only relevant for Series other case
7915 other = ops.maybe_prepare_scalar_for_op(other, (self.shape[axis],))
7916
7917 self, other = self._align_for_op(other, axis, flex=True, level=None)
7918
7919 with np.errstate(all="ignore"):
7920 new_data = self._dispatch_frame_op(other, op, axis=axis)
7921 return self._construct_result(new_data)
7922
7923 _logical_method = _arith_method
7924
7925 def _dispatch_frame_op(
7926 self, right, func: Callable, axis: AxisInt | None = None
7927 ) -> DataFrame:
7928 """
7929 Evaluate the frame operation func(left, right) by evaluating
7930 column-by-column, dispatching to the Series implementation.
7931
7932 Parameters
7933 ----------
7934 right : scalar, Series, or DataFrame
7935 func : arithmetic or comparison operator
7936 axis : {None, 0, 1}
7937
7938 Returns
7939 -------
7940 DataFrame
7941
7942 Notes
7943 -----
7944 Caller is responsible for setting np.errstate where relevant.
7945 """
7946 # Get the appropriate array-op to apply to each column/block's values.
7947 array_op = ops.get_array_op(func)
7948
7949 right = lib.item_from_zerodim(right)
